results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

Dick Hensold is the leading Northumbrian smallpiper in North America, and for the past 20 years has performed and taught in England, Scotland, Japan, Canada, and across the United States. (He is a regular instructor/ performer at the Piper's Gathering event in VT.) 

His solo Northumbrian smallpipes CD Big Music for Northumbrian Smallpipes was released in 2007. He is based in St Paul, MN. His solo concert features Northumbrian smallpipes (a quiet bagpipe from Northeast England), reel pipes (an indoor version of the Scottish Highland pipes intended for Scottish dance music), seljefløyte (Norwegian willow-flute), säckpipa (Swedish bagpipes), pibgorn (Welsh hornpipe), and several other instruments. He plays music in several traditional and historical styles, with particular emphasis on Cape Breton, early Scottish, and Northumbrian, but also including Scandinavian, medieval, Irish, and original music. The program also includes a couple of songs, neither of them in English, and a limited amount of dancing while seated. Reservations http://www.eventbrite.com/o/notlob-music-6730833315

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

results.description:
Join us again this Thursday morning before you head out to work for a guided meditation of Scripture in the Jesuit tradition of Lectio Divina (Sacred Reading). All faiths (or non-faiths) are welcome! Alice will be facilitating.


What is Lectio?

Lectio Divina is an ancient Christian practice of unhurried, contemplative meditation on a portion of Scripture following four basic movements: 

Lectio: a time of slow repeated reading of Scripture punctuated by the use of a bell or chime. 

Meditatio: A time of quiet reflection on God's words and presence. 

Oratio: A time of silent conversational intimacy with God. 

Contemplatio: A time of listening for God's words for us personally.

We hope you'll join us in this deeply enriching spiritual practice.

results.description:
How Monthly Practice Sessions Work

The intent of these sessions is to provide a safe, comfortable, informal place for you to gain confidence and practice with speaking.

YOU DO NOT NEED TO BE PREPARED TO ATTEND THESE MEETINGS. They are meant to help you become prepared.


Each attendee will get a chance to head to the front of the room and practice a speech if you so desire and feel you are ready.


The speech can be:

• Your elevator pitch

• a portion of a prepared speech

• a speech prepared just for these sessions

•  an impromptu speech.


You are also welcome to just come and learn from other attendees.


The limit of each individual presentation is determined by the number of participants for that session (generally under 10 minutes).

I hear from many participants, "I almost didn't come because I didn't have time to prepare, and I wasn't sure how it would go. I'm so glad I came. I learned so much and am walking away with much more than I ever thought possible. I feel more confident now in introducing myself. Thank you, Kim!"

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Speaker:
Samir Mitragotri, Ph.D.
Director, Center for Bioengineering
University of California, Santa Barbara 

Safe and effective administration of therapeutics is a major challenge in today’s healthcare. The challenge is especially prominent for biologics which are increasingly dominating the therapeutic landscape. Current methods of drug delivery have several limitations including the use of needle-based injections in case of biologics and lack of targeting in case of small molecules. Mitragotri's laboratory is developing novel methods to directly address these challenges. They have developed transdermal and oral delivery methods that offer a painless and needle-free alternative to injection-based methods for delivering drugs such as insulin and vaccines. Mitragotri's laboratory has also developed novel strategies for targeted drug delivery using nanoparticle-based systems. Nanoparticles are widely explored to improve the therapeutic outcome of small molecules. However, poor vascular circulation, limited targeting and the inability to negotiate biological barriers have prevented the overwhelming majority of nanoparticles from entering the clinic. Mother Nature has provided us with many examples of successful ‘particles’ of her own in the form of viruses, bacteria and circulatory cells. They have developed biologically-inspired and bio-mimetic nanoparticle systems to target drugs to the diseased site. Mitragorti will provide an overview of these systems with respect to their principles and capabilities.

Host:
Ali Khademhosseini, MASc, Ph.D.
Associate Faculty member, Wyss Institute for
Biologically Inspired Engineering at Harvard University
Professor at Harvard-MIT's
Division of Health Sciences and Technology (HST),
Brigham & Women's Hospital and Harvard Medical School
results.name: Bioinspired, Bioengineered and Biomimetic Systems for Drug Delivery

results.description:
This free workshop will help you articulate your complete why story in three steps:

1. We’ll help you fashion your purpose story. 
2. We’ll coach you in how to present your story. 
3. And then we’ll capture your story on video.

First you’ll gather your stories and tell your most purposeful one with the help of a partner. Then you practice presenting with a clear and expressive voice, and when you’re ready we’ll capture your story on video.

The workshop will be led by Author & Publisher Jenny Hudson, Actor, Singer & Voice Coach Celia Slattery, and Videographer & Business Coach Brad Powell.

Register on Eventbrite >

Questions? Click Here for More Details >

Do you know the purpose, cause, or belief that inspires you to do what you do?

When people gather to talk about their work, or their big business idea, they usually start by talking about what they do. In fact, the most common greeting at a networking meeting is the question, “What do you do?”

But, giving your job title is the wrong answer. People don’t choose to work with you, because of what you do. They don’t buy what you do, they buy why you do it.

Presenting logical data and facts doesn’t work well because hardly anyone will remember. But people do remember a good story – especially if you tell your why.

Note: Everyone will be able to share and develop their why stories, but we’ll only have time to personally coach and shoot video with a couple of participants while the rest of the group watches and learns from their example. 

This two-hour workshop is a preview of our two-day “The Game Changer Workshop.” 

<a href="http://www.publish-promote.com"></a>

This free workshop will help you articulate your complete why story in three steps:

The workshop will be led by Author & Publisher Jenny Hudson, Actor, Singer & Voice Coach Celia Slattery, and Videographer & Business Coach Brad Powell.

Becoming More Strategic  
#WESTstrategic
http://www.westorg.org/2015-09-24-more-strategic

Women tend to get stuck in the “weeds,” focused on details and perfection rather than the bigger picture. This workshop talks about the five shifts that will help them move into a more strategic mindset, understanding their value and increasing their impact.

More about Jodi

Jodi Detjen has been a professor of management at Suffolk University since 1999. Jodi teaches management at the MBA, Undergraduate and Corporate Education levels both online, in the classroom and internationally. She co-authored The Orange Line: A Woman’s Guide to Integrating Career, Family and Lifein May 2013. She now focuses on consulting and leadership development on these principles in her consulting firm, Orange Grove Consulting. Prior to teaching and independent consulting, Jodi was as an international management consultant based in London, England working with Global 1000 clients focused on large-scale organizational change. Jodi received her MA in International Development Policy focusing on organizational development from Duke University and her BSc from Virginia Tech in Management Science.

results.description:
As summer winds down and school gets back in session, Tech in Motion Boston will be hosting our first ever Back to School Demos & Drinks! This interactive and informative event will feature local startups who are completely transforming the education space with technology. From cloud-based solutions, to Artificial Intelligence, get a taste for all that ed-tech has to offer! 

Join us at EF's headquarters in Cambridge to explore this growing relationship between technology and education. You’ll get a chance to network and chat with some of the coolest startups in the ed-tech space. Not to mention, EF is hosting an open bar and we will be providing pizza!

Our Demo Companies:

AcademicMerit, founded by a former high school English teacher, is a Boston and Portland, ME -based educational-technology company that provides cloud-based solutions for teacher professional development, student assessment, and differentiated instruction. Setting AcademicMerit apart from other companies in the ed-tech space is our pioneering of a competency-based model of teacher professional development that has been endorsed by a wide range of stakeholders, including Bill Gates himself—and has resulted in a multi-year partnership with The College Board that will make AcademicMerit the pedagogical and technological platform for most AP® courses.


AERobot (Affordable Education Robot) is a simple low-cost robot designed for introductory programming and robotics education, starting from a late primary or middle school level. The hardware is inexpensive enough to make it accessible to a wide range of audiences, with the intent of enabling every student to have (and keep, and personalize) their own robot. Activities and software have been developed, tested and refined through popular week-long pilot sessions with several dozen rising fifth through eighth graders in the summers of 2014 and 2015.


Brain Power, founded by neuroscientist Dr. Ned Sahin, is a scientifically-driven technology company that has created the world’s first wearable educational system for children with autism.  The Brain Power System consists of a family of game-like apps that help children with autism to teach themselves crucial life skills, including eye contact, emotion recognition, conversation skills, and self-control.  The system leverages smart glass hardware, sensors, big data, and predictive analytics, to produce data-driven quantitative insights into how each child's unique brain learns. The Brain Power System keeps children heads-up, and engaged with the world around them. Find out more about our upcoming Kickstarter, at www.Brain-Power.com/kickstarter


Cognii uses Artificial Intelligence to provide automatic assessment of students' open response answers. With Cognii's intelligent tutoring, students are engaged in active learning, receive personalized feedback, and construct answers themselves—a powerful way to learn and retain information. We work with educational organizations to facilitate high-quality formative assessment across grade levels and subjects in K-12, higher education, and professional learning. Cognii improves students’ learning outcomes, optimizes educators’ time on grading work, and lowers the cost of delivering engaging education.  Cognii is similar to Apple’s Siri, Microsoft’s Cortana, Google Now and IBM Watson, but with a singular focus on education.  

Education First  is most widely known as the world's leading international education company.  You may be surprised to hear that technology, design and innovation are always at the core of our work in travel, language learning, cultural exchange and education.  From launching what has grown into the world's largest online English school with Apple back in the '90s, to our more recent work with LinkedIn on democratizing credentialing for global language learners, our innovation teams experiment with cutting edge and emerging technologies while driving our mission of opening the world through education.   

EdX is a nonprofit, open-source learning destination offering online courses from more than 75 member institutions. Founded by Harvard University and MIT, edX is focused on transforming online and classroom learning through groundbreaking methodologies, game-like educational experiences and cutting-edge research on an open-source platform.

Empow Studios brings technology, arts, and play together to help young learners discover and build on their creative talents using today's sophisticated technical tools. We teach classes in programming, robotics, video game design, animation, design, audio engineering and other creative skills for the 21st century. We're always looking for talented technologists who want to contribute to kids' education, and educators who want to learn technology. 


General Assembly is creating a global community of individuals empowered to pursue work they love, by offering full-time immersive programs, long-form courses, and classes and workshops on the most relevant skills of the 21st century – from web development and user experience design, to business fundamentals, to data science, to product management and digital marketing. Established in early 2011 as an innovative community in New York City for entrepreneurs and startup companies, General Assembly is an educational institution that transforms thinkers into creators through education in technology, business and design at fourteen campuses across four continents. 


GymSnap was founded by two lifelong friends, Joe Rockland and David Stanton, who both experienced frustration in college when they repeatedly showed up at the gym, only to find that it was too busy to use any of the equipment. Joe and David took the opportunity to improve the fitness and recreation experience for college students across the country, creating a mobile platform to inform students of the level of occupancy at recreation facilities. They saw this as a significant problem that they could solve for students and universities alike. In 2014, David started working on the initial wireframes for what would become GymSnap. In early 2015, Joe joined David to work on this project and GymSnap was born. David and Joe want GymSnap to help students stay healthy and still have time to experience all of the other amazing experiences college has to offer. 

Listen Current makes it easy to bring authentic voices and compelling non-fiction stories to the classroom. We curate the best of public radio to keep teaching connected to the real world and build student listening skills at the same time.


Storyboard That is an award winning online storyboard and graphic organizer creator. Our intuitive Storyboard Creator features a drag and drop interface and thousands of assets that we created in-house. Storyboard That’s customers include educators, businesses, and individuals all over the world looking to create high quality and engaging visual assets that aid critical thinking, communication, and collaboration.


Thync is small portable device that enables you to feel calm or energy on demand. Wear it for just a few minutes and feel the effects for hours. Thync combines proven neuroscience with groundbreaking technology, enabling users to access inherent abilities and achieve more in the course of your day. The effects are similar to a shot of espresso or glass of wine - without ingesting anything. Thync Calm or Energy Vibes are delivered and controlled using an iOS app. Our mission at Thync is to unlimit you. Press a button, feel great. 

ValoreBooks is an online textbook marketplace that helps students save up to 90% off the cost of new and used textbooks, and get the price when they want to sell them back. In 2015, Valore acquired Boundless, a learning solution that empowers educators with access to open-source content, quizzes, slides and assessments to create higher quality course materials at lower costs for their students. By serving the entire education ecosystem, from schools and bookstores, to professors and educators, and of course, students, Valore is leading the way toward a more affordable education.   

-----------------------------------------------------------------

As always a huge thank you to our monthly sponsors Jobspring Partners and Workbridge Associates. 

For live updates on the meetup follow us on Twitter @Tech_in_Motion, @JobspringBoston and @WorkbridgeMA. We look forward to meeting you at this fun-filled networking event. Feel free to bring a friend along!

Interested in sponsoring Tech in Motion? Reach out to Courtney or Cara!

Julie Rodriguez presenting Decoding Data Visualizations


Designing data visualizations presents us with unique and interesting challenges; how to deliver important information in a clear and understandable format; how to tell a compelling story to our audiences; how to make visualizations efficient. In this talk, Julie will share a few visualization techniques and connect those back to her compiled data visualization pattern library. Julie willintroduce methods to reveal insights into data comparisons, connections, and conclusions. 

How do we analyze and compare attributes?​ ​How do we show associations and links between data sets?​ ​How do we discover themes?

Data visualization methods are at the core of extracting meaning from data. Together, attendees will explore and examine various design ideas.
results.name: Decoding Data Visualizations

results.description:
{Come to this powerful event to learn how to use the power of habits and rituals for you, rather than against you.}

Neurological research seems to indicate that 90% or more of what we do is habitual. 


We will explore the current science of habit formation, and how to apply that to your life. New habit development is the single most leveraged action you can invest your willpower in.

The habits of Belief, Perception, Thinking, and Action are the keys to transforming who you experience yourself to be and what you accomplish in the world.

In this evening we will go beyond habit development to the high return on investment practice of rituals and routines. 

Where as a single habit is very beneficial, a new routine or ritual creates the patterns of life that create enjoyment, effectiveness, and success.

Through videos, discussion and exercises, Matthew will help us learn how to identify, create and establish new habits, routines, and rituals.

To Prepare ....

1.)  We will look at how to change ineffective habits.
What is one current result in your life, that you are not satisfied with. Can you identify the habit that keeps it that way?

2.) We will explore how to create new habits.
What is one practice, or way of being that you have “wanted” to begin or maintain, but have failed to develop the habit? What do you believe was in your way?

3.) We will identify the power of routine and ritual to shift us from “Doing” to “Being in Action”.
How much do you accomplish from force, discipline or willpower? Would you rather create it from enthusiasm, grace, and alignment?

Our Leader This Evening

Matthew Winston is a PGN Organizer and a long-time practitioner of Law of Attraction.   Matthew took his first personal growth seminars in 1992, and a decade later joined the Board of Insight New England.

Matthew has been a corporate trainer and consultant for over 20 years. For the last 7 years he has moved into personal coaching and small group workshops. His practice, OneSingleThing, focuses on three major areas: relationship coaching; entrepreneur coaching; and awakening coaching. He is also the owner of Kids OT To Play, a pediatric occupational therapy, speech therapy and behavioral therapy clinic.

results.description:
Public speaking with ease and impact in front of any group.

Imagine standing in front of any audience, feeling absolutely confident and at ease.

Whether you have public speaking anxiety or simply want to express yourself with greater clarity the experience in a Speaking Circle® will guide you toward effortless authenticity

Speaking Circles help:

Business professionals become more effective, authentic and powerful. 

People expand their vision of what life could be like when they are able to

be fully present, confident and authentic. 

People who suffer from stage fright to overcome their fears.

Hope to see you soon,

Dexter Nardella

At a Speaking Circle you are provided all the support you need to express yourself in your own time and in your own unique way, without fear or discomfort. Some call this depth of expression, “speaking from the heart,” “the authentic self” or “your real voice.” Whatever you call it, you know when you are there; you know when someone else is there.  Click to read FAQs about a Speaking Circle.  

http://www.speakingcirclesinternational.com/Articles/Principles/FAQ.html#.VKx9y0c76rU

results.description:
If interested, RSVP. Looking up pricing on the 14th and will post options. Be prepared to shell out $100+

THE GENRE-DEFINING HIT!

Rejoice, Book of Mormon followers, for the worldwide phenomenon that knocked Wicked off its sparkly broomstick is coming to you on a massive nationwide tour, hitting the Emerson Colonial Theater in Boston, MA, showing until 11 Oct 2015.. There's absolutely no need to book your plane tickets to NYC, as this Tony Award-winning musical sensation is heading your way....

From the four-time Emmy Award-winning creators of South Park, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, comes this outrageous comedy musical about a pair of mismatched Mormon inductees who are sent on a mission to a place that's about as far from Salt Lake City as you can get.The musical was written in collaboration with Robert Lopez, the Tony Award-winning writer of Avenue Q, and co-directed by Mr. Parker and three-time Tony nominee Casey Nicholaw (Spamalot, The Drowsy Chaperone).

With a roof-lifting 19 original songs that range from filthy, to obscene, to sweet and full of heart, this is sure to win over everybody (although perhaps don't bring your local pastor).

WHAT IS THE BOOK OF MORMON ABOUT?

'The greatest time of a Mormon kid's life is his mission,' sings Elder Kevin Price before finding out where and who with, his journey starts. But things are not as the handsome and pious Elder Price predicted, when he's paired up with the hapless and roly-poly Elder Cunningham and sent to...UGANDA! Disneyland, this isn't.

The adventure unfolds as Elder Price and Elder Cunningham try to preach "The Book" to a local community destroyed by disease and ruled by an evil war lord. Meanwhile the disaster-prone duo learn about themselves, the true meaning of friendship and what their religion ultimately means to them. Get your tickets for the hottest show in town, and the most outrageous!

DID YOU KNOW?

Instead of picketing Broadway or theaters nationwide as originally feared, The Mormon church has taken the good-natured and risque lampooning of The Book Of Mormon with a wry grin and have instead taken out advertisements in the show's playbills across the world, under the heading 'The book is always better'. Now that is what we call a darned good sport!

- See more at: http://www.boston-theater.com/theaters/colonial-theater/the-book-of-mormon.php#sthash.z3ftAhFb.dpuf
results.name: Book Of Mormon

results.description:
Like sands through the hourglass, this is the week of BostonJS. We have two (2) thrilling talks lined up for this Thursday, and—fun bit of trivia—zero (0) of them are from the talent pool here at Bocoup. That’s right: the BostonJS submission engine is gaining steam, but don’t go hot-gluing any brass gears to your tophats just yet—we still need you up there at our ramshackle lectern.


…It was a steampunk joke. The joke was… that we are “gaining steam,” but you shouldn’t… fully affect the garb of a steampunk enthusiast? With the gears and such, on a tophat. I guess. Okay whatever these descriptions are free anyway here are your speakers for the evening:


Making a book viewer from Google Books APIs
Kate deBethune

A short talk about how I put together a simple book viewer using a couple of Google Books APIs and which allows the user to perform keyword searches against the Google Books database and then select a book to preview in a viewer. Makes use of JavaScript, JQuery, AJAX, JSONP, and Google Books APIs.

Functional API Testing with NodeJS and Mocha
Daniel Bostwick


Few people test as much as they think they should, and even for those who often write tests, there is a lot of confusion around different types of tests, how to structure and name tests, or even what to test. 

In this talk, Daniel Bostwick will walk through how he structures a NodeJS project for testing, integrates the Mocha and Chai testing frameworks, discuss the guidelines he usesfor figuring out what to test, and show an examples of how to functionally test a backend API. You'll come away with a better knowledge of BDD, and hopefully inspired to better test your own APIs. 

All this and more, this Thursday night. Five dollars will get you an entire seat, but you’ll only need the edge.
results.name: BostonJS: `Navigator.requestWakeLock()` When September Ends

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own questions, personal experiences, and realizations. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.
results.name: Join us as we discuss A Course In Miracles and apply its principles to our lives

group.name: A Course In Miracles Discussion Group - Carlisle

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the downstairs bar and look for the sign!

results.description:
Ongoing class in 18th century Scottish Broadsword and Smallsword.

The Broadsword is the archetypal weapon of the Highlander swordsman - a broad-bladed cutting and thrusting weapon. It has a basket hilt to protect the hand and wielded single-handed.

The Smallsword is the courtly weapon of the Scottish warrior class. An elegant thrusting weapon it teaches the fighter to use the thrust and make small parries. The smallsword is the immediate predecessor to modern epee.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.

All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Scottish Smallsword & Broadsword

Are you feeling scary, sweet, devilish or sexy? Then let’s shake up your portfolio with some new images, just in time for Halloween.  (Photographers: see an important note about dues below.)

The RiversEdge Photographic Society is looking for 4 female models and 1 male model to participate in our annual Halloween themed photo shoot.  If you have some great Sexy costumes and are feeling just a little devilish, this is a great chance to get portfolio-quality images created in a professional studio.  Profesional costumes wiil also be provided, but please also bring yours as we cannot be sure of correct fit.


We are casting for a MUA, but please come prepared to do your own hair and make-up, in case there is a problem.


If you would like to model for this shoot, please respond via email, that includes a phone number, ASAP to [masked] so I can put you on our list.  We will finalize our cast for the shoot about 7 days before the shoot date. 


The shoot will be held at Studio Imaging 637 (http://StudioImaging637.com/), on Thursday evening, Sept. 24th.  Models should arrive by 6:30 pm to begin makeup and the shoot will last until 10pm. Models must be at least 18 years old and will need to sign the club's model release. 


There will be multiple photographers and 3-4 sets dedicated to creating images that present you in a frightening manner.  Please bring at least 2 different outfits to model. This shoot will be limited to 4 female models and 1 male model, so if you are interested, please respond soon so that you can be considered for the shoot. The RiversEdge Photographic Society provides a creative and supportive community with a special focus on the art and science of people photography: portrait, glamour and fashion photography, studio lighting and related subjects. The club includes many experienced portrait photographers. This is a great opportunity to have fun, get some different new pictures for your portfolio, make contact with several excellent photographers, and learn about participating in future club events.  Models will receive images from all the photographers they work with. 


You can visit the club's Meet Up site at:


http://www.meetup.com/RiversEdge-Photographic-Society


Please visit our Facebook page where you can browse through pictures from our past shoots: 


http://www.facebook.com/pages/Rivers-Ed … 213?ref=nf


The studio is near the River St. exit off Rt 93 on the Andover/Lawrence boarder, at 637 Andover Street ,  Lawrence, MA (http://StudioImaging637.com/ )


Photographers: you must be a paid RiversEdge member to photograph at this shoot.  The dues for the[masked] club year will be $120, and a first installment of $60 will be due on the date of this shoot. Additionally, following our usual custom, photographers will need to pay a $10 shoot fee to the club and (generally) a $10 shoot fee to Studio Imaging 637 in order to photograph at this shoot.

results.description:
Abortion is not really talked about much in film even though it is constantly talked about in the news! For this meetup we will focus on two movies about abortion: "4 months, 3 weeks and 2 days" by Cristian Mungiu and "Obvious Child" by Gillian Robespierre. One is a intense drama and the other is a romantic comedy. I think they provide great contrast to discuss how abortion is or can be presented in film.

In addition to these films we can tie in other films that show abortion or have it as a central topic. Also importantly I want to discuss movies where abortion was ignored when it probably wouldn't have been IRL. If you want to shout out certain movies or good articles on this topic comment below! 

Accessing the movies: You can access 4 Months, 3 Weeks,and 2 Days on Hulu or rent on Amazon Prime for $2.99. You can get Obvious Child on Netflix DVD or stream on Amazon Prime.
results.name: Controversial Film Topic: Abortion

As KiNK, the Bulgarian native has always stuck to his guns. And those guns are drum machines, synthesizers, analog beauties, and antique rarities. It's as hard to keep your eyes off his magical powers as it is to close your eyes and soak in the structure of his amazing sound.

results.description: Friday mornings are really simple. It's simply silence. Usually 6 to 10 or so people - most don't reserve through meetup. We sit for 40 minutes or so and then have tea. It a great group of wonderful friends and we've been sitting with different people coming and going for nearly 10 years! The best thing you can do to learn how to meditate, or to stabilize or deepen your practice, is to sit with others who are simply abiding in the natural state of peace. It's contagious.  It's our natural state.  It's just that simple.  Peace, Judy

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
As part of our ongoing work to innovate on how best to solve big social problems, we're about to embark on a prototype test that we'd like to invite you to join. In a nutshell, we're studying "mass aggregation" - which means bringing together lots of individuals to pool together their efforts and resources, and make a big difference in the world. 


We view this as a first step in building a vibrant community that could combine its time and money on an ongoing basis - kind of like a virtual country made up of like-minded citizens. That said, it's early days -- we're pressure testing the concept and working out the kinks. We know we would really benefit from your help and feedback, and we think this will be fun! 


Here's the ask: We need about 5-10 minutes of your time each day for nine days, starting on Friday, September 25th. Essentially we'll be playing a virtual simulation game. You'll be given some imaginary money to play with and we'll ask you to make decisions about how you'd like to allocate that imaginary money and your time to solve social problems. Every day during those weeks you'll be asked to take a simple action (e.g., rate an idea, raise some questions) toward this end. 


This shouldn't make total sense to you at this point (we can't give too much away in advance) but we think it will be easy and enjoyable. Are you game to join us?


If so, email me at keith at billionsinstitute.org. I'll sign you up, and then you'll receive your first instructions on September 25th.
results.name: Mass Aggregation Prototype Test

results.description:
Get your tickets to author Elizabeth Gilbert's book reading and discussion focused around her latest book "Big Magic: Creative Living Beyond Fear". For those that are interested, we'll grab a drink nearby in Harvard Square following the event.


NOTE: Tickets are predicted to sell out, purchase yours here:  https://www.eventbrite.com/e/elizabeth-gilbert-at-first-parish-church-tickets-17327969423

"Harvard Book Store welcomes award-winning author of Eat, Pray, Love ELIZABETH GILBERT for a discussion of her latest book, Big Magic: Creative Living Beyond Fear.

Readers of all ages and walks of life have drawn inspiration and empowerment from Elizabeth Gilbert’s books for years. Now this beloved author digs deep into her own generative process to share her wisdom and unique perspective about creativity. With profound empathy and radiant generosity, she offers potent insights into the mysterious nature of inspiration. She asks us to embrace our curiosity and let go of needless suffering. She shows us how to tackle what we most love, and how to face down what we most fear. She discusses the attitudes, approaches, and habits we need in order to live our most creative lives. Balancing between soulful spirituality and cheerful pragmatism, Gilbert encourages us to uncover the “strange jewels” that are hidden within each of us. Whether we are looking to write a book, make art, find new ways to address challenges in our work, embark on a dream long deferred, or simply infuse our everyday lives with more mindfulness and passion, Big Magic cracks open a world of wonder and joy."

CREDIT: http://www.harvard.com/event/elizabeth_gilbert/
results.name: BOSTON: Elizabeth Gilbert Book Reading & Post-Event Drinks

results.description:
$59 per person
Discover the beauty of nature at night as you paddle through calm waters under the glow of the summer moon. We believe a full moon enhances the beauty of these secluded waters and creates a truly memorable adventure. On this leisurely excursion, you'll paddle comfortable, stable kayaks and get a chance to experience nature up close. After a short paddling demonstration, your experienced guide will lead you on a revealing tour, sharing interesting facts about the area's history and the surrounding landscape. As the moon rises higher in the sky, you'll start to see the fascinating wildlife that emerges when the sun sets.

This spectacular tour only occurs during the weeks of the full moon and is a special adventure you won't want to miss. No prior kayaking experience is needed. All necessary paddling equipment is provided.

What to Bring Print checklist (PDF)
•Weather-appropriate clothing (preferably synthetic*)
•Waterproof jacket and pants
•Personal prescriptions such as EpiPen or inhaler

Optional
•One-quart water bottle or hydration system
•Waterproof camera
•Water shoes or closed-toed shoes you don't mind getting wet
•10-foot or longer recreational kayak, paddle and US Coast Guard-approved Type III PFD†
•Extra change of clothes
•Towel

What We Provide
•Use of all necessary paddling equipment: boats, paddles, PFD's, etc.
•Closed-toed water shoes
•First-aid kit
•Water
•Insect repellant

In order for you to confirm your space please visit www.llbean.com/dedham, find the specific time and date of your event, and complete the registration (and payment process (as necessary).  We look forward to seeing you!
results.name: Full Moon Kayak Tour

results.description:
We are a group of friendly easy going soccer players that need a few more people this next season for our team. Come to the first game for free and if you like it sign up for the full Season.  The games are 5 on 5 counting goalies. There are no boards in this league.  All skill levels are welcome.


This league is less competitive and tends to be more social and easy going than other leagues. There are 4 teams total so it is a good way to meet people quickly as you play many of the same teams often and get to know the players.   Games are at 7PM and 8PM each Friday night.  People on the different teams are often friends and hang out at the bar attached to the gym after the many of the games.  Men must be over 30 years of age and ladies over 27 to join.

The first game is Friday 9/25/15 at Boston athletic club at 7PM. Show up a little early to meet people and get ready. Must bring shin guards. 

If you want to sign up for the full season click this link below and select (Friday over 30's)  Sign up soon before it is too late. It should be from $75 to $95 for 13 games depending how many people are on the team and cost is divided up.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1D3wbmtqYSaTlnkWegqnpp4emOfhdUv5b5LC7ISwUX_o/viewform?c=0&w=1

results.description:
This event showcases three very different types of communication with the Spiritual Realm. Three very different women, three ways of communicating with loved ones in Spirit, Spirit Guides, Angels and Archangels. 

Andrea Kukulka is a gifted healing medium connecting you to your loved ones in Spirit, your guides, angels and archangels to bring you information you need in your life right now. Andrea delivers messages of hope, love and healing to support you in your journey and reassure you that the loving relationships you had have not ended, only changed. 

Amy Antonellis specializes in Table Tipping, a form of physical mediumship where the energy of the angel or person in Spirit uses the table and Amy to transmit a very physical sensation of their love and healing as well as their messages. Questions unspoken are answered by Spirit, further confirming the information and verifying the support and connections you have from the other side.


Kristi Johnston is guided by Spirit to draw images of loved ones who have passed, angel guides or totem animals. She draws these upside down, contrary to her normal drawing method. These images bring further confirmation that our time here on earth is not all there is, and the unseen world is real and accessible.  The sketch is gifted to the person for whom it was drawn.


The connection of these three women to each other and to Spirit provides a completely unique experience for all those in attendance. Individual messages are not guaranteed, however messages of love, healing and reassurance are sure to resonate throughout the room. 

 
*** Fee for this event is $45*** 
**Pay here privately with eventbrite**

*Seating is limited to 20 to insure more personal messages*
results.how_to_find_us: Downtown Mansfield, just past Cheng-Du and before the Fire Station.

Compositions marking significant Longy milestones and anniversaries

SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 27 American Songbook and Broadway Revue | 4:00 PM Harvard University Science Center Plaza   An afternoon of popular songs and Broadway classics presented by Opera at Longy   Sponsored by Harvard University; no tickets required.

Date and time:
Friday, September 25th 2015 from 7pm to 8:30pm (or later if we decide to go somewhere else after).


Public Transportation:
It is located in downtown Boston, on the corner of Summer Street and Arch Street, across from the Macy's and CVS at Downtown Crossing T [Boston subway] station (Red Line and Orange Line). It is a 5-minute walk from South Station (various T, bus, and train connections), a 5-minute walk from Park Street T Station (Green Line), and a 7-minute walk from State Street T Station (Blue Line).

Parking:
There is a paid parking lot a few blocks away at 100 Federal Street, across from the Bank of America building between Franklin Street and Matthew Street. After 5pm, the cost is $10 flat for the day.

Let me know if there are any other questions. See you then!

I'll be at the theater early to meet you before we go inside and I will post a comment letting you know where we are going after the movie. Everest (2015)

On the morning of May 10, 1996, climbers (Jason Clarke, Josh Brolin) from two expeditions start their final ascent toward the summit of Mount Everest, the highest point on Earth. With little warning, a violent storm strikes the mountain, engulfing the adventurers in one of the fiercest blizzards ever encountered by man. Challenged by the harshest conditions imaginable, the teams must endure blistering winds and freezing temperatures in an epic battle to survive against nearly impossible odds.

Beginner: Struggling to make clean connections between your favorite tracks? Let Mmmmaven’s own Fens walk you through the basics of transitions in DJing, and teach you how to incorporate different approaches across a variety of genres.


This basic lecture will teach you about the factors that help decide which practices are best for the style you play, and a few tricks to help you establish good practices to help you survive any situation.

About your instructor:

Fens has been an integral part of our school from the very beginning. With hundreds of hours of teaching under his belt, it’s only perhaps eclipsed by his time in the booth. He’s opened for superstars, headlined himself and organized and ran with his own squad independently for years.

results.description:
Required Membership Level: Bronze (or above). Membership must be paid or acquired before you RSVP. DO NOT RSVP BEFORE PAYING (Click Here).

Gold and Bronze Memberships entitle you to attend great events like this one!

MOVIE  / GENRE: TIME TRAVEL 


I love the subject of time travel. Whether the subject is dealt within  the non-fictional realm of theoretical physicists such as  Einstein, Kip Thorne, Stephen Hawking and Michio Kaku, or in novels and film I can’t get enough of it.  And I shouldn’t neglect to mention  purely philosophical speculations on time.

The main thrust of—what I hope will be a recurring series—will be novels and (if feasible) movies. The fictional material is, of course, immense. This past weekend alone I watched two recent films (both 2014): Predestination and Edge of Tomorrow: Live. Die. Repeat. I loved Twelve Monkeys, I have the DVD of The Time Traveler's Wife, which I also enjoyed. Who can leave out the classic that may have—not sure—created the genre: H.G. Wells’ The Time Machine. There are so many; I’ve seen more than a few but so many, many more I've  never seen (or read).


Our first ever private film screening will be a viewing of Frequency, directed by Gregory Hoblit, with Dennis Quaid in the starring role. The movie touches on questions relating to parallel timelines and the "Grandfather Paradox," combined with a chilling crime drama. Click on the Wikipedia article for more detail. I think that Frequency will be a great kickoff for our ongoing series of time travel movies and discussions.

*****************************

Please consider joining the Radio Roundtable Member Pool!
results.name: FREQUENCY. A movie directed by Gregory Hoblit (Genre: Time Travel)

results.description:
As a follow-up on our recent education presentation about light painting, this is the associated field trip. We will meet in Quincy Quarries, a great location do practice light painting (the rock and ground surfaces), light drawing and writing (in mid air or in combination with the painting). Below are some inspirations. If the sky is clear, we will also get star trails and the quarries have some unique views from above.

The following equipment is a must-have: tripod, camera with manual settings and a remote control/intervalometer are highly recommended. Bring batteries and all cables you may need for that.


In addition, wear hiking boots, because the terrain is quite uneven. And any kind of light gadget that you may have, from flashlights to toys that light up. I will have a collection with me that I'm happy to share, including that light-up frisbee. :-)

results.description:
Join the Photography Workshops' Fall Photo-School

Starting on Friday  September 24, Photography Workshops will be offering a 6 session photo-school for just sixphotographers looking to improve their skills and learn new techniques.
The school will offer six sessions (three evenings and three full day location classes) that will cover a wide range of photography from abstract,  macro, and stunning landscapes to creative portraiture. You will learn to direct a viewer's eye around your image, and master advanced compositional techniques.  Instruction will be given on mastering the finer points of depth of field, metering modes and creative exposure plus you will get plenty of hands-on experience shooting during our indoor and outdoor sessions. 

If you have never experienced an intense series of workshop in a very small group setting you have really missed out.  Don't let this chance slip by. This series has run several times in the past three years and because there are only eight spaces available  it has always filled within days,

Three of the sessions will run on Friday evenings from 7.30pm  - 10pm at Ian Murray Photography in Pembroke. . The other three sessions will be full day outdoor workshops on Sundays:


1. Advanced Camera Control
Friday Sept 25th  7.30pm - 10 pm indoors at 201 Oak Street Pembroke

Metering

Exposure Compensation

Bracketing

Creative use of Exposure

Creative Depth of field

2. Advanced Composition
Sun Oct  25  outdoors 10am - 5pm Boston

Get beyond the rule of thirds and explore:
• The Gestalt of image composition
• How the viewer's eye will move around your image.
• Creating images which deliberately lead the viewer
• The Gestalt of points, lines and curves
• Create the impression of depth in your images


3. Advanced Landscape Photography
Sunday Oct  4th - Fall Foliage Landscape trip to Vermont 7am - 10pm

• Managing Color
• Compositional techniques for better landscapes
• Working with the light
• Thinking in Black and white

4.  Macro Photography
Friday  Oct 16th  7.30 pm-10pm Indoor location 201 Oak Street Pembroke


• Fine tuning depth of field
• How close is too close
• Creative Macro - from real to abstract
• Flowers, Foliage and Food
• Lighting for Macro

5. Developing Your eye
Friday NOV[masked]pm - 10pm Oak Street Pembroke.


• Thinking photographically
• Seeing shapes and patterns
• Photographing emotion
• Engaging the viewer
• Shooting light and shadow
• Shooting concepts

6.  Portraiture
Sunday Nov 29  15 9am - 12 noon , and 2pm - 5pm Outdoors Area


• Simple Head shots
• Full body portraits
• Group Portraits
• Location Portraiture
• Lighting setups for great portraits
• Portable lighting
• Posing Techniques

Unlike most photography schools this will be a unique opportunity to experience quality instruction in a very small group (8 max) that will ensure  lots of attention. It will provide a unique mix of indoor classroom style learning coupled with full day workshops on location. The cost of just $575 covers all six classes, handouts, exercises and image review giving more than 40 hours of quality instruction with professional photographer, Ian Murray for less than $15 per hour. At the end of the sessions  Ian will conduct a detailed review and critique of twenty of your images. 

Please note:  The fee does not include meals or travel costs to the various locations. However, car pooling may be available.

Ian Murray is a professional photographer with over 40 years of experience. He is also a fully trained and qualified teacher of adults having a graduate degree in education. He works full time as a portrait photographer and is regularly hired  to photograph concerts and music festivals. He has been widely published including having his work appear in the book "Images that Inspire" Wiley 2009.  You can check out his web-site at:

http://www.ianmurrayphoto.com

or call him for more details at[masked]

Payment plans are available for this class. A scholarship may also be available towards the cost of this series, please contact Ian for details at [masked]

See what others have said about Ian's workshops:

I just had a class with Ian at my usual group night. He kindly led a portrait workshop for us. I was blown away by this guys knowledge and teaching skill. I have spent thousands of dollars to hear and see the 'best in the business' but I found Ian to be by far the best I have ever seen. His patience, humor, and willingness to give up his knowledge is unique and extremely refreshing. I wish I had discovered him years ago. He taught us more in two hours than I have gained in days from other teachers and he made it all so easy. I will definitely be spending more time at Ian's classes and I would recommend him to anyone who is serious about learning photographic skills. Ian is certainly the best photography teacher in New England and I susoect he ranks in the top five in the USA. He should be charging ten times what he currently charges - and if he did it would still be great value! I urge you to join this group and attend his workshops. ”

— Robert Reed on Jan 24, 2013.

“ This was a great workshop! Ian was a great teacher. He explained everything in a clear, concise manner. He displayed great patience and good humor! I would highly recommend this workshop to any beginner interested in learning their camera and how to improve their photos! ”

— Debi on Dec 31, 2012.

“ I appreciate the workshops Ian offers because it's focused on imparting wisdom vs. centered around talking at us or bragging. I've been to some workshops where I didn't learn a thing other than how large the ego of the facilitator was so I appreciate that I leave these workshops better educated than when I went in. ”

— Jean Gaudet on Apr 23, 2012.

\

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description:
Here's a chance to see a new French film that sounds fascinating and could lend itself to a good group conversation after.


Thirty-year-old Alice is a sailor about to embark on a journey she will not soon forget. Leaving her fiancé Félix ashore, she joins the crew of an old cargo ship, the Fidelio, as a mechanic. Once on board, Alice discovers that she is replacing a man who has just died and that her first great love, Gaël, is the ship’s captain. Lulled by life aboard the ship and entranced by the limitless horizon of the wide-open ocean, Alice succumbs to desire and begins an affair with Gaël. But she soon faces a difficult choice about what will make her truly happy: an unfettered life at sea, or grounded happiness at home?


Lucie Borleteau’s provocative and sensuous directorial debut brings to the screen a powerful female protagonist in an almost exclusively male world, while Ariane Labed’s fearless performance as Alice reveals a confident, independent woman fully in command of her own sexuality, grappling with conflicting desires. (France/Greece, 2014, 97 min.) In French, Romanian, English, Tagalog, and Norwegian with English subtitles.

Part of the MFA's New French Cinema program. You may want to buy your ticket in advance online.


We'll meet in the museum just outside of the Remis Auditorium (there is a cafe/wine bar nearby as well as the entrance to the bookstore and gift shop). We'll meet in the same spot after the film, and for those who want to, begin an odyssey for a drink or meal.
results.name: Fidelio, Alice’s Odyssey

Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

Boston's biggest sketch comedy event returns, with the 2015 BEST OF BOSTON SKETCH COMEDY show! Each night of this fantastic run of shows, we feature three of Boston's best independent sketch comedy teams, bringing their weird, wild, and over-the-top hilarious comedy to you! results.description:
Please register on the webpage to indicate you will be joining us and to receive updates


http://www.doortotheoutdoors.com/d2o-events/2015/7/18/summer-summit-series

Summer in Boston is short, so join us as we seek adventure and create lasting memories in New England. Whether it is your first summer or your last summer in Boston, make it count by enjoying time with friends, having new experiences, and seeing new sights. As part of the D2O Summer Summit Series we will hike a series of natural places in New England for both fun and exercise, before old man winter returns. Each hike provides a workout and a unique adventure, so lace your sneakers or boots, dust off your backpack, and do it for the gram. We guarantee likes for pictures from the final summer summit, Mt. Eisenhower.

Summit Locations, Days, & Times:
- Fells Reservation (MA) – Saturday, July 18: 11am - 2pm

- Breakheart Reservation (MA) – Sunday, August 16: 1pm - 4pm

- White Mountains - Mount Eisenhower (NH) – Saturday, September 26: Most of the day

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS

Do I need hiking boots?

No, but if you have some we suggest you wear them or if you enjoy hiking but haven’t purchased a pair of books yet, we welcome you to break your new books in with us, but these hikes do not absolutely require hiking boots. You may be more comfortable with hiking boots, especially for the final summer summit.

Is transportation provided?

The first two summits are MBTA accessible and we will try to organize car-pooling, zipcars, or a van. However, the final summer summit, Mt. Eisenhower, is approximately 3 hours from Boston, so we will work on a way for those without a car or do not want to drive to join us. More information will be provided to those that registered.
results.name: Summer Summit Series (Final Hike)

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course.

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM. 

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

Full marathoners (17 miles):

http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/540338834


Half marathoners(10 miles):

http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/541153126

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
The Greenway Challange is a multi-segment relay race that has a different course every year. This year's race starts in Sutton, MA and travels through the Blackstone River Valley before ending in Lincoln. The course covers about 60 miles and consists of the following segments:

• run 2.2 miles

• road bike 21.0 miles

• paddle 2.7 miles

• run 6.2 miles

• road bike 18.2 miles

• paddle 2.3 miles


• run 3.1 miles


• mountain bike 4.2 miles

An additional "challange" is that each team has to travel from transition area to transition area transporting all of the participants and their equipment in a single vehicle.

This will be our ninth year competing in this race. Last year there were 100 teams that finished the race – our team finished 21st in our category and 46th overall. While our team is full, it would be fun to get a few other teams (or solos if you're up for it) from the Random Group of Hikers into the race.

Registration is open now and closes the day before the race – information about what to do can be found using the link below. Let me know if I can answer any questions or help you put a team together. If you're interested in participating in this event then RSVP YES to this event and use the comment section below to communicate with others who might be looking for others to form a team.

www.greenwaychallange.org

Please join us for our 5th Out of the Darkness Walk - Our team name is Team Alicia & Maria - 

The Out of the Darkness Community Walks are the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention's (AFSP) signature fundraising campaign, bringing together family, friends, colleagues, and supporters at 3-5 mile walks in hundreds of communities across the country.

When you walk in the Out of the Darkness Community Walks, you join the effort with thousands of people to raise funds and awareness for AFSP's vision to create a world without suicide. 

The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention is at the forefront of research, education and prevention initiatives designed to reduce loss of life from suicide. With more than 38,000 lives lost each year in the U.S. and over one million worldwide, the importance of AFSP's mission has never been greater, nor our work more urgent.

Any contribution will help the work of AFSP, and all donations are 100% tax deductible

You do not have to make a donation to walk- Thank you for your support!

Race starts at 10:00 am at the Waltham Common. Suggest getting there at 9:30 or even 9:00 am. Uncertain how many runners are anticipated or how prepared the event is for many runners. Benefits the Edinburg Center :
http://www.edinburgcenter.org/please-join-the-edinburg-center-for-the-sixth-annual-rock-into-recovery-on-saturday-september-26th/
For the sixth year in a row, The Edinburg Center will host the Rock Into Festival on Saturday, September 26th on the Waltham Common.
Event festivities will begin with the Rock Into Recovery 5K Fun Run/Walk at 10:00 AM. The route starts on the Waltham Common, continues on a scenic route alongside the Charles River, proceeds around the old Watch Factory, then loops back to the Waltham Common where the Rock Into Recovery Festival will take place from 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM.
The Rock Into Recovery 5K is USATF certified. In addition, we are proud to be participating in the RAW Series (Race Around Waltham) this year! For more information about the 5K, please click on the link below:
https://racewire.com/register.php?id=5455
This year’s Rock Into Recovery Festival includes:
Live Music
Ramblin’ Dan Martin, The Residentials and Jon Cohan & His Golden Rulers!
Food & Refreshments
An array of delicious food and grilled items!
Children’s Activities
Flippo the Entertainer, face painting, balloons, pumpkin patch and more!
Arts & Crafts
Paintings, jewelry and a variety of local artwork!
Information and Resources
Statewide community organizations and programs!
Over the last five years, Rock Into Recovery events have attracted hundreds of people to the Waltham Common for this very unique annual event! This year we anticipate that many individuals including the people we serve, their family members, our staff, our sponsors, our state legislators as well as state-wide mental health and addiction service providers, artists and community members will join with The Edinburg Center on Saturday, September 26th!
Rock Into Recovery brings the magic of live music and hope to the community and helps people learn more about the reality that recovery from mental health conditions and addiction is an attainable goal for the persons we serve.
We look forward to seeing you once again this year to Celebrate Recovery!
results.name: RAW Series Race #10 - Rock into Recovery 5K Run / Walk

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.
results.name: (Arlington) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling
