results.description:
Starting Point:  India Point Park.  Free Parking in the Lot and on India Street.  Check the pointer in the map link. 

************** ITINERARY **************

Depart from India Point Park, cross over to E. Providence via the newly completed George Redman Linear Park on the Washington Bridge, then enjoy a scenic ride on the East Bay Bike Path to Independence Park. 


Continue to the Blithewold Mansion which has a spectacular view and garden.  If time allows, we'll stop by Colts State Park on the way back.


************** LOGISTICS **************


Approx. 30 miles round trip - plan 2 hours bike ride each way at moderate speed (10-12 mph).  Mostly flat and paved but this is not an easy breezy ride because there is a lot of ground to cover.  Therefore make sure you can handle the activity level (speed and distance) before signing up. This ride is NOT FOR BEGINNERS.

*********** PAY ATTENTION ***********


#1  In order to get free admissions into the Blithewold Mansion and Gardens (normally $12), you MUST reserve free tickets ahead of time from the following website: http://www.smithsonianmag.com/museumday/venues/blithewold-mansion-gardens-arboretum/

Click on "Get Tickets" and register.  Then print or save the ticket to your phone.

#2  Bring plenty of water (not sure if there are refill stations along the bike path), sunscreen, bike helmet and lock.  You should arrive having food in your stomach and taken care of the business (use the restroom).


#3  Bring a packed lunch/snack (preferred to save time) or $$ to purchase food.  If you must purchase food, there is a Shaw's Supermarket along the route and cafes in Bristol.

*********** TRANSPORTATION ***********


If you need carpool or can offer rides, please put your location in the Comments section and work out the details offline.  Make sure to exchange email / phone #'s.

Suggested carpool fee: Minimum $10 payable to your driver as a courtesy and to share cost of gas.


***************** RENTAL *****************


The nearest bike rental shop is East Providence Cycle about 2 miles from the starting point.  If you need a rental, call the shop ahead of time to inquire availability and cost.  You need to complete the rental and travel to the bike path (or to our starting point) to join the group.  Make sure to plan extra time that morning.

http://j.mp/1OSLzWz

http://eastprovidencecycle.com/

results.description:
(This event is presented by the Partnership of the Historic Bostons and an RSVP is recommended at http://bcd2015saugus.eventbrite.com)

The Puritans who founded the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1630 were driven by a commitment to their religious ideals and beliefs. But it was Scottish prisoners of war and other non-Puritans who did the dirty work, building the tools for a new colony as the flow of material goods from England dwindled. In keeping with our Food and Drink of 17th-century Boston theme, we'll discover how workers at the Saugus Iron Works ate, drank, and lived.

On this unique and intimate visit to the Saugus Iron Works, learn the inside story of the first successful industrial site in the United States. You’ll meet the rough-and-tumble laborers who brought industrial technology to New England. The tour includes a hearth cooking demonstration in the forge.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

results.description:
The Israelite nation was developing its own identity and culture, but they were on the brink of destruction. The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

results.description:
So a vague plan formed in the pub the other day to have a day trip to Quincy Quarries, and next Saturday looks like it should work.


Quincy Quarry is, as the name suggests, a quarry just outside Quincy. It has a shedload of top-roping routes ranging from a set of friendly-looking 5.6s in little railroad, to some pretty burly looking routes in the 5.11 range on the overhanging Q-wall. There is even a single, solitary, route than can be led.
Other popular activities in the quarry include graffiti, drinking, smoking weed, and disposing of bodies.


You can very conceivably get there by public transport from Boston: take the red line to Quincy center and then the 215 bus. If anyone has a car, however, the journey will be much simpler. Car pooling would be much appreciated, I'm sure.


I'd suggest we meet under Q-wall in the main quarry at about 11:30am - if you're coming from the car park it's the first one you come to, on the right as you enter.


Good topos are available on mountain project along with an aerial map of the quarry so you can orient yourselves:
http://www.mountainproject.com/v/quincy-quarries/105908121

==Gear: [ please read carefully ]==


Most routes have expansion bolts above them for setting up a top-rope. A decent rack for Quincy will involve about 8-10m of rigging rope or thick tape, a handful of locking carabiners (min 4 per anchor), and a 50m rope or longer. The rock is pretty stable, but a helmet would be a smart move.
Obviously the number of people who can go at any time is limited by the number of ropes etc, so please make it known in the comments if you have a rope to offer, or rigging gear, or will be relying on other people. I'm sure we're happy to share, but it would be wise not to turn up and expect to climb all day just using other people's equipment, especially if ropes are limited. Alternatively if you decide you're not going to turn up make this clear too - ropes are heavy and we don't want to drag them down for a no-show.


Guidebooks: there's a decent set of routes in 'Rock Climbing: New England', and (I'm told) a more comprehensive list in 'Boston Rocks'. Mountain project is also a good resource for the quarries - if you've not got a book, do download the app.
results.how_to_find_us: parking lot and if running late look to kwall (outside corner route)
results.name: Day trip to Quincy Quarries

results.description:
This year marks the  Berklee Beantown Jazz Festival's fifteenth anniversary and the theme is Jazz: The Voice of the People.

It has become an event tens of thousands look forward to attending each year. The music is outstanding, there is a variety of delicious ethnic cuisine sold from vendor tables, numerous items for sale such as clothing, jewelry, and various novelties in addition to business and non profit informational tables from which you can get many giveaways.

On Saturday September 26th the festival celebrates musical styles and artists from around the globe in a free outdoor setting with performances on three stages along Columbus Ave in the South End of Boston.

Here's a link with highlights from 2014, https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=A8WCoV1hzwg

This is Rain or Shine.

2015 PERFORMANCE SCHEDULE

12:00 pm - Natixis Global Asset Management Stage

The Berklee City Music All-Star Ensemble is comprised of the best and brightest rising young stars from the Berklee City Music program, a national nonprofit enabling youth from underserved communities to develop musically, academically, socially, and emotionally, primarily through the study of contemporary music.

12:00 pm - Berklee Stage

Felix Peikli and the Royal Flush Quintet are a unique and unparalleled group of artists under the direction of Peikli, an internationally acclaimed clarinet virtuoso, artist, and entertainer.

12:00 pm - Capital One Stage

Award-winning pianist and composer Caili O'Doherty celebrates the release of her debut album, Padme, which features a diverse mix of original compositions inspired by her experiences teaching and playing music in North America, Panama, Colombia, and West Africa.

12:45 pm - Natixis Global Asset Management Stage

iRESI is a jazz quartet led by Carlos Averhoff Jr. featuring jazz luminaries Francisco Mela on drums, John Lockwood on bass, and Aruan Ortiz on piano.

1:15 pm - Capital One Stage

Marty Walsh is a virtuosic guitar player, formerly of Supertramp, who will perform an eclectic and wide-ranging set drawing on Tom Major's (Entrain) funk and ska roots, Danny Morris's R&B, Matt Jenson's reggae, and Dino Gonovi's jazz and funk influences.

1:15 pm - Berklee Stage

Educator, arranger, and award-winning composer Omar Thomas performs with his big band, the 18-piece Omar Thomas Large Ensemble, and special guest Stefon Harris.

1:45 pm - Natixis Global Asset Management Stage

Bass player, bandleader, and songwriter Alissia serves as the "future face of funk music," according to the Huffington Post.

2:30 pm - Capital One Stage

ChoroBop's music is a melting pot of good influences that calls upon the nuances of bebop jazz with a healthy dose of choro; the trio has recently displayed its energy and finesse at at venues including Carnegie Hall and the Blue Note.

2:30 pm - Berklee Stage

Four jazz luminaries, including National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Master and Kind of Blue drummer Jimmy Cobb, join together to lovingly pay tribute to John Coltrane and the music of his time. We Four also includes Javon Jackson (tenor saxophone), George Cables (piano), and John Webber (bass).

2:45 pm - Natixis Global Asset Management Stage

Singer-songwriter Paige Bryan, winner of a USA Songwriting Competition award, performs; her new EP, A Mile in Stilettos, will be released later this year.

3:30 pm - Capital One Stage

Bass virtuosos Victor Wooten and Steve Bailey join forces for a performance not to be missed.

3:45 pm - Berklee Stage

David Gilmore performs in support of his latest project, Energies of Change. Gilmore, an associate professor in Berklee's Guitar Department, has recorded and performed with artists including Wayne Shorter, Dave Douglas, Sam Rivers, Steve Coleman, and Cassandra Wilson, among others.

4:00 pm - Natixis Global Asset Management Stage

Grammy Award–winning drummer, composer, and bandleader Terri Lyne Carrington has toured extensively with luminaries like Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter, Al Jarreau, Stan Getz, and David Sanborn, to name just a few. For this year's festival, Carrington's Mosaic Project will be joined by soul/R&B singer Jaguar Wright.

4:50 pm - Capital One Stage

Eguie Castrillo, a mind-blowing, world-renowned percussionist, performs with his big band, the Palladium Nights Orchestra.

5:00 pm - Berklee Stage

George Garzone, one of the most influential saxophonists of our time, performs with other acclaimed musicians John Lockwood (bass), Bob Gullotti (drums), and Leo Genovese (piano), along with the Teros String Quartet. Tribute to John Coltrane & Stan Getz.

5:00 pm - Natixis Global Asset Management Stage

New Orleans native Ledisi has recorded six albums, earned eight Grammy nominations, performed at the White House for President and Mrs. Obama on several occasions, and earned a place in the pantheon of the best soul singers of her generation.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

The High Notes of Jazz Roxbury mini tours will be led by Discover Roxbury at 2 pm, 3 pm and 4 pm with a cost of $5 cash per person per tour.

Sign up for a tour at the Discover Roxbury's booth near the Massachusetts Avenue intersection. Suggest you sign up no later than 15 minutes before the tour starts.

Once Boston's "jazz mecca," Lower Roxbury was the site of some of the most famous clubs and after-hours venues on the East Coast, home to hundreds of Pullman Porters, and the stomping grounds for many people who would later become prominent Civil Rights activists. Hear unique and complex narratives, many drawn from personal anecdotes and memories told by former musicians, residents, and club owners, that weave a fascinating tapestry of this historic community and a forgotten period of Boston and American history.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Public transportation is strongly recommended because it will be extremely difficult to find parking nearby.

MBTA:

Check out MBTA or Hop Stop to plan your route.

ten (10) minute walk from:

Ruggles Station - Orange Line

or

Mass Ave Station - Orange Line

five (5) minute walk from:

# 1 Mass Ave bus (Mass Ave and Columbus Street stop)

Do you deserve to have the body you’ve always wanted? Absolutely. Does a child struggling with terminal illness deserve a ray of hope and satisfaction? Of course they do. 


These things happen. The stories are made everyday, children fighting for their lives are shown compassion through the Make A Wish Foundation. They bounce back. They’re kids after all. And the wishes granted by Make A Wish have far-reaching effects in the lives of kids’ friends and family. 


At TFW Boston, we also make stories.  Women and men can bounce back too, sometimes it just takes a coach to empower them. Help us make a wish come true. Lose fat, gain strength, support charity, feel amazing. 


RSVP for the “Workout for a Wish” charity event! 


Its sponsored by TFW Boston and the Make A Wish Foundation of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, Saturday, September 26 @ 12PM --- 7th Floor, 33 Harrison Ave, Boston MA, 02111.  


Change a child’s life, and maybe even your own.

results.description:
(A set of 6 Saturday classes)

Rapier – The word evokes images of duels, high adventure, and swashbuckling. Have you had a desire to learn how these swords were used in combat during the Renaissance era? Much more than shouting “En Garde!” and assuming a guard stance; competent warriors fought with systems that included various ways to attack and defend, footwork, timing, and even rules of dueling, all based on a sophisticated understanding of body mechanics, mathematics and philosophy.

The 16th century was a period of change for the sword. No longer relegated to the battlefield; the sword changed as its wear became commonplace in society. Blades slimmed and guards became more elaborate as the sword evolved into a nimble thrusting weapon worn by commoner and noble alike. As a result, a number of fencing schools opened to capitalize on their growing popularity. The golden age of rapier study dawned around 1550; numerous masters publishing fencing system manuals over the century to follow, with topics including rapier, off-hand companions such as the dagger, buckler and cape, long sword, quarterstaff, pole arm, dagger alone, and grappling.

Our six-week Novice Rapier course will introduce the basic techniques and vocabulary of rapier fencing, enabling students to begin their study of period combat and the Art of Defence. The course will be taught by Charles and Robert, rapier scholars and Schole of Defence instructors.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

We invite you to come join the scholars and combatants of our Schole!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes [August 22, 29, and September 5, 12, 19 and, 26] and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  Class materials will be sent via email before the first session.)

results.description:
The Berklee Beantown Jazz Festival is Boston’s biggest block
party—a free, annual outdoor concert open to the public that has delighted hundreds of thousands of music lovers over the years with its host of jazz, Latin, blues, funk, and groove performances, along with an array of food vendors and free activities for kids. Each year, the festival is theplace to be in Boston on the last Saturday in September as the community comes together in a bond forged in the joy of great live music.

Watch a video recap of the 2014 Berklee Beantown Jazz Festival here:

https://youtu.be/A8WCoV1hzwg

Highlights include nine-time Grammy-nominated R&B artist Ledisi, Javon Jackson with legendary drummer Jimmy Cobb, Terri Lyne Carrington, with Philly-based soul/R&B vocalist Jaguar Wright; singer/songwriter Paige Bryan; rising funk bassist Alissia Benveniste and the Funketeers; and others. Faculty and alumni also play a major role with performances.

Stretching across six blocks in Boston’s historic South End, the festival offers world-class music on three stages, phenomenal food and drink, arts, crafts, and unique gifts. The Natixis Family Park offers facepainting, inflatables, cotton candy, KidsJam, an instrument petting zoo, and more.
Columbus Avenue between Massachusetts Avenue and Burke Street.

Crossposted in other groups
http://www.meetup.com/Fun-Bostonians/events/224806548/
among others.

The 43 bus would normally go down Tremont st toward this festival. It will probably still get you close and you can just walk over to the meeting place (Good eats pizza), I picked that place because you can GPS it.

Look for joe at the pizza place. He will be hosting this event because I can no longer do it. 100+ from meetup are going alone. The Berklee Beantown Jazz Festival is Boston’s biggest block party—a free, annual outdoor concert open to the public that has delighted hundreds of thousands of music lovers over the years with its host of jazz, Latin, blues, funk, and groove performances, along with an array of food vendors and free activities for kids. Each year, the festival is theplace to be in Boston on the last Saturday in September as the community comes together in a bond forged in the joy of great live music.

https://youtu.be/A8WCoV1hzwg

Highlights include nine-time Grammy-nominated R&B artist Ledisi, Javon Jackson with legendary drummer Jimmy Cobb, Terri Lyne Carrington, with Philly-based soul/R&B vocalist Jaguar Wright; singer/songwriter Paige Bryan; rising funk bassist Alissia Benveniste and the Funketeers; and others. Faculty and alumni also play a major role with performances.

Stretching across six blocks in Boston’s historic South End, the festival offers world-class music on three stages, phenomenal food and drink, arts, crafts, and unique gifts. The Natixis Family Park offers facepainting, inflatables, cotton candy, KidsJam, an instrument petting zoo, and more.
Columbus Avenue between Massachusetts Avenue and Burke Street.

The 43 bus would normally go down Tremont st toward this festival. It will probably still get you close and you can just walk over to the meeting place (Good eats pizza), I picked that place because you can GPS it.
http://www.meetup.com/Fun-Bostonians/events/224806548/
results.how_to_find_us: JOE WILL BE YOUR HOST MEET HIM AT THE PIZZA PLACE AS USUAL. He is posted as host in Social fun as well.

results.description:
Queridos amigos,

Gracias por vuestra participación en la última reunión.  Y muchísimas gracias a Stan, que a pesar de su apretada agenda laboral, dedicó el tiempo para preparar y hacernos una muy buena presentación que nos ayudó mucho a entender mejor “Pedro Páramo”.  Y una cordial bienvenida a Andy, Hector y
Victoria.

Tal como comentamos en la charla, en septiembre comentaremos “El tiempo entre costuras” de María Dueñas.  La sinopsis de este libro, que en las palabras de Mario Vargas Llosa es “una novela maravillosa, con intriga, amor, misterio y ternura”,  es la siguiente: www.casadellibro.com/libro-el-tiempo-entre-costuras/[masked]/[masked]  El libro está disponible en Schoenhof´s a un precio de $12.80.  Sin embargo, antes de visitar la librería para comprar el libro, os recomiendo que os contactéis con Schoenhof's [masked]), identificándoos como miembros del club de lectura para verificar existencias.   

La lectura para octubre será “El libro de arena”, una colección de relatos de Jorge Luis Borges.  La sinopsis de este libro, una de las obras más tardías del autor, es la siguiente: www.casadellibro.com/libro-el-libro-de-arena/[masked]/562304 El libro estará disponible en Schoenhof's a un precio de $22.36 después de nuestro descuento.  Aquellos que deseéis comprar el libro en Schoenhof´s, que me aviséis por favor. 

Por último, os recuerdo que estamos en plena temporada de planificación de la lista de lectura para 2016.  Si tenéis recomendaciones, ahora es buen momento para hacérmelas llegar. 

¡Muchas gracias y espero que os guste el libro de María Dueñas y que paséis un feliz verano!

Un abrazo,

Mark
results.how_to_find_us: La reunión se celebrará en la sala al fondo de la librería.
results.name: En septiembre: "El tiempo entre costuras" de María Dueñas

results.description:
Fall is here, and we should take advantage of the beginning of the beautiful Autumn weather by heading north to Brooksby Farm and doing a classic New England Activity!  Of course, we'll stock up on apple cider and donuts as well.  Plus, your huge pile of apples will give you an excuse to make that apple pie you've been craving.

http://www.brooksbyfarm.org/


The time we get home is flexible, but plan to arrive by 12:45! Tentatively, we'll plan to meet at Davis Square and Central Square. However, we'll see where people would like to meet, and different groups can meet in different squares. If you have a car, please let me know- anyone who is coming but doesn't have a car will contribute toward paying for gas, and if you have a car, you come free. If you have a ZipCar membership, that works too, and everyone can split the cost (but don't reserve it til you hear back that we need it!).  Brooksby Farm is only 30 minute drive away, so we should have plenty of time to explore.  Because we need to figure out driving, RSVPing with what you actually end up doing is doubly important.  

Be on the lookout for an email with instructions Friday night!

Come full enough that you won't get hungry but hungry enough to eat some apples and donuts!

Looking forward to seeing you on Saturday!

NEW RSVP POLICY: Please RSVP if you plan to come. If you RSVP, I'll be waiting for you, so please show up! If you change your RSVP or ditch us within 48 hours of a meetup more than once per calendar year, we'll have to remove you from the group.  Two members have been dropped so far.  When you RSVP, you're making a commitment and taking a spot, so come. If you need to get a hold of me, my number is four four zero 488-5055.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet up in squares in Cambridge/Somerville and carpool to the farm!
results.name: Apple Picking: A Fruitful Adventure

Hi Urban Sketchers!  Let's take advantage of the Beantown Jazz Festival and sketch!  There should be interesting opportunities to sketch musicians, people in the audience, or just the beautiful architecture in the South End.

Let's meet at Southwest Corridor park at 201 Camden St. (in between Dilworth St. and Watson St.) promptly at 2pm.  From there, we can disperse to sketch, and then reconvene at 4pm to share our work.


Here's some information regarding the festival:

https://www.berklee.edu/beantownjazz 


The Berklee Beantown Jazz Festival is Boston’s biggest block party—a free, annual outdoor concert open to the public that has delighted hundreds of thousands of music lovers over the years with its host of jazz, Latin, blues, funk, and groove performances, along with an array of food vendors and free activities for kids. Each year, the festival is the place to be in Boston on the last Saturday in September as the community comes together in a bond forged in the joy of great live music.

This year’s festival, themed “Jazz: The Voice of the People,” will take place from 12:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Saturday, September 26, 2015 at Columbus Avenue between Massachusetts Avenue and Burke Street.

Stretching across six blocks in Boston’s historic South End, the festival offers world-class music on three stages, phenomenal food and drink, arts, crafts, and unique gifts. The Natixis Family Park offers facepainting, inflatables, cotton candy, KidsJam, an instrument petting zoo, and more.
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet at Southwest Corridor park at 201 Camden St. (in between Dilworth St. and Watson St.)  I'll be wearing a green backpack.

results.description:
--We will explore the walking paths at three connected parks, which are in the Newton, Needham, Dedham, and West Roxbury borders.  

1. Nahanton Park


Located in Newton's southwest corner and has a current configuration that dates from 1981 and supports some 55 acres of unique habitat that includes a varied environment of meadow, woods, wetlands, a pond, a large soccer field, and a beautiful woodland path for the disabled that borders the Charles River.


http://www.nahantonpark.org/images/nahantonparkmap.pdf

2. Cutler Park

Cutler Park Reservation stretches from Kendrick Street in Needham to Great Plain Avenue in Dedham.  Its prominent features include 1.5 miles loop of Kendrick Pond and the Charles itself. Other features include a large freshwater marsh, and glacial eskers and drumlins. Railroad tracks cross the park in the south.  

3. Millennium Park


The park used to be a landfill hill. Today it consists of six miles of handicapped-accessible walking trails, playing fields, a canoe launch on the Charles, a nature trail, and wonderful views of the Blue Hills, Newton's hills, and downtown Boston.


http://www.newtonconservators.org/map34millennium.htm

Be prepared for about 10miles of walking/easy hiking.  Bring water and any needed snacks.  Wear sneakers or walking shoes.  Parking is available inside the park. (Post any questions) Thanks!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the Nahanton Street entrance/parking lot.
results.name: Hiking and Walking: Nahanton Park + Cutler Park + Millennium Park

results.description:
Due to several requests we will be going back to The Breakheart Reservation in Saugus. We will be walking 3-4 miles.  

We will be inviting several meetup groups.

Breakheart Reservation is a 640-acre hardwood forest with jagged, rocky outcroppings, two fresh-water lakes, and a rambling section of the Saugus River. Seven rocky hills, over 200 feet high, provide vistas of Boston, southern New Hampshire and central Massachusetts. An extensive trail system through the woodlands guides visitors to various areas of the reservation. Fishing in Silver and Pearce Lakes, hiking the trails and birdwatching by the Saugus River are popular year-round activities.

We will meet at the Christopher P Dunne Visitor Center. You will need either hiking shoes or sneakers. Bring water and snacks. Afterwards, we will grab a bite at a local restaurant.

If you miss the hike join us at Polcari's

Directions: From north or south: Take Rte. 1 to Lynn Fells Parkway exit, follow Lynn Fells Parkway a short distance, take a right onto Forest Street. Park entrance is after Kasabuski Rink.  

Parking: At the end of Forest Street; and if full, try the little lot along side the skating rink which leads to the back of Ocean State Job Lot/Target where there is plenty of parking.

Maps: Available on this page

http://www.saugus.org/FOBR

Afterwards we will go to the famous Polcari's Restaurunt on Rt 1 for dinner and drinks. 

Liability Waiver 

 As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at <a>www.hikesafe.com;</a> the leader(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

Safety First!

results.description:
Calling all classical musicians of all skill levels to get together and play with each other as soloists or in groups. I am a pianist and violinist and want to create a regular venue for other amateur classical instrumentalists to play for and with each other in a fun and encouraging environment (music + talking + drinks). Jamming is also encouraged so feel free to bring chamber music that we could read through together. The music room has a grand piano and 3 music stands.

We've had 2 meetups with pianists, violinist, violists, flautists, clarinetists, and a ukulele player.  The formats are various: piano solos, string duos, piano+clarinet, piano trios (w/ clarinet), and even a string quartet with a cello substitution.  ;-)

NOTE:   Please RSVP and keep it up-to-date so we can all have a sense of what instruments will be present.
results.name: Get together and play for each other (3rd time)!

results.description:
In this FREE mini-workshop, you'll learn specific tools that you can use right away to master intimate connections that are meaningful and loving.  

Spend your afternoon MELTING INTO LOVE with a group of like-minded friends (old and new!)


If this feels scary to you and you've been holding yourself back, this workshop is for you! 

Discover what's in your way of having the most satisfying  relationships including effective communication, and great sex. 

This workshop will focus on our innate ability to open to a greater love inside ourselves - that can be shared with others: a skill that when learned and practiced, enhances all of our relationships.  Feeling deeply connected to yourself and your heart provides a deep sense of peace. 

You’ll learn specific tools that will:

• Enhance your ability to identify core wants, needs and desires 

• Cultivate communication for healthy relating

• Become more intimate with yourself and others - with ease! 

• Stay in a place of love when it’s most difficult

In this free mini-workshop, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with others through a variety of exercises designed to open your heart and support you in sharing authentically with one another.

Come and get a taste of what you’ve been craving in a totally safe, warm, loving and non-sexual environment.  Learn more about what the Human Awareness Institute has to offer.

Finding love and being in love every day is something I personally never dreamed was possible (only for 'others' and not for me!)  Well, I'm happy to say I was wrong and am really excited to share what I've learned with you.

Each event begins promptly at the scheduled time. Please arrive at 2:45 pm so you can settle in, register and meet a few folks before we begin promptly.   

There will be no admittance after the scheduled start time so as not to break the continuity of the workshop.  



We look forward to seeing you there!  Even if you've been to a mini-workshop before, please join us again!  There's no limit to how many you can attend!

results.description:
Have never been to this so I want to get this on the calendar while I'm thinking about it. It takes place in Union Square in Somerville, the home of the marshmallow goodness called fluff :) Will post more details when it gets closer.
https://unionsquaremain.org/fluff-festival/
results.name: 10th Annual Fluff Festival

results.description:
Save the Date for this year’s Fluff Festival.  It will take place on Saturday, September 26, 2015  from 3 pm to 7 pm in Union Square, Somerville, MA (raindate Sunday, September 27).

“What the Fluff?” is expected to attract 10,000 Fluff fans. A whole range of games, music, shenanigans, cooking contests,  on-going throughout the festival. The festival is free with no charge for the games and contests. 


https://vimeo.com/15905952

“What the Fluff?: 10th Annual Fluff Festival” honors the illustrious Fluff creator, Archibald Query, who concocted the gooey sticky spread right here in Union Square in 1917. On Saturday, September 26, 2015 local artists, musicians, theatrical performers, inventors, and humorists pay madcap tribute to the creation of this great American foodstuff on two stages.

Vendors will have a variety of crafts & food inspired by Fluff. Fest-goers can sample the taste of Fluff from our local vendors presenting sweet and savory Fluffalicious delights like Fluff Pizza, Fluff Tacos, Fluffanutta Donuts and lots and lots more. Area businesses get into the spirit too, turning over their menus. Fluff-inspired cocktails and Fluff-topped beer are on tap at nearby restaurants.

Fluff games and shenanigans will spread the sticky goodness throughout the Union Square. Fluff jousting, Fluff Musical Chairs, Blind Man’s Fluff and even Fluff Hair-Dos show that its perfectly okay to play with your food.

The Main Stage will be packed with local artists. The Flufferettes were originally a music group in the 1930s that promoted Fluff on the radio for Durkee Mower, the makers, of Marshmallow Fluff. We bring that group alive each year for the visual age as colorful and sassy song-and-dance performers. The ladies of Rogue Burlesque return to the festival with their unique brand of gorgeous, geeky burlesque. All in all, get ready to dance!

Making sure that the action never stops, there’s fun at every turn including tricks from Wheels n Motion BMX Stunt Team, stilt-walking workshop from the Open Air Circus and tunes spun by DJ Roy Van.

Sink deep into the sugary fun by creating a mallowey concoction for the cook-off. The winner gets a private, behind-the-scenes tour of the Durkee Mower Fluff Factory.

Where: Union Square Plaza in Somerville. Where Prospect Street, Washington Street and Somerville Avenue meet. 

Cost: Free ! 

Activities: Performance Stage: Musical performances by Federator No 1, Emperor Norton’s Stationary Marching Band and the Dirty Dottys with special theatrical presentation by the Flufferettes as interpreted by Rogue Burlesque. 

Cooking Contest: Whip up an original recipe with Fluff or present your best interpretation of a classic. The Cooking Contest Grand Prize Winner gets a tour of the Durkee Mower Fluff factory, a one-of-a-kind trophy and gift certificates to local businesses. 

Shenanigans Stage: All the big, messy Fluff games have their own stage with games including Fluff Lick-Off, Blind Man's Fluff, Fluffer or Nutter Relay, Fluff Hair Dos and Fluff Jousting. 

Fluff Games: Pin the F on Fluff Boy, Fluff Fishing, Pyramid Toss and the game of culinary roulette we call Fluff Fear Factor. Win prizes! All Fluff Midway Games are free. 

Vendors: Buy Fluff treats and Fluff inspired items from whoopie pies to Fluffernutters.

results.name: What The Fluff?!! - 10th Annual Fluff Festival

results.description:
I'm excited to announce this one as 500px is my favorite photo community... look for my pics under Dena A.

On September 26, 2015, 50px is hosting a global photo walk held at the same time in cities all over the world. The goal of this photo walk is to meet fellow photographers, learn, make new friends, and capture inspiring images. Our host in Boston is Molly Kate.

This years theme is "Explore With Friends." We're to shoot photos with friends and show what makes Boston Special, shine a light on Boston's hidden gems, favorite photo spots, and everyday life.

The official hashtags are: #500GPW15 and #500pxGPW15Boston. Use these to tag all photos from the walk.

Timing and Route: The Boston Area Meetup Group will meet outside Fox 25 News at the corner of Beacon and Park 15 minutes prior to the 500px walk. The 500px walk commences at 4P at the steps of the State House. The route will travel the esplanade.

After the GPW, all are welcome for dinner and drinks in the Copley/Back Bay area.

Checkout photos from last years walk at:  https://iso.500px.com/500px-global-photowalk-collection-2014/

results.description:
Be part of this special event of the Union of Minority Neighborhoods' Boston Busing/Desegregation Project (BBDP).

From BBDP:

"Part performance and part dialogue, BBDP members and audience will come together to listen to each other's stories, discuss how the workings of race and class keep us stuck, and think about ways we can move forward, individually and collectively.

Based on BBDP's report, Unfinished Business: 7 Questions, 7 Lessons, the Talkabout will touch on the school desegregation crisis in Boston, but we also want to examine how the issues that were at play then are still with us today and how things may or may not have changed."

The BBDP always has a wonderful way of creating a community experience.  Come be part of this one.  You'll be glad you did.

This meetup is for those that are interested in getting together with other Art Journalers and creatives.  Bring your art journal, your paints, markers or collage materials and create with others that love to create too.  There's always some great conversations and inspiration going around. 


You should bring with you something crafty you'd like to work on.  Or you are welcome to buy materials you need in the store before sitting down.  Kept Creations is a full retail craft store. 


These meetups don't include instruction or class materials but provide a seat and creative place to get some of your artsy projects done.  Some people like to draw, color, work on cards, journal or even scrapbook.  As long as it's crafty, bring it and be crafty with us.

Art Journaling is a great way to express yourself through paper, paint, ink, markers, drawing or more.  The possibilities are endless.

results.description:
This workshop will open your eyes to a whole new world of photo opportunities. Have you ever wondered how to capture those magical, dramatic images with deep blue sky, or a golden glow? In this double feature workshop you will discover the secrets of  both Golden Hour and Blue Hour Photography. I am limiting the size of this class to 15 so please RSVP right away.

Golden Hour By the Charles River Suzanne Merritt

 Golden hour refers to that intense, then soft golden light just before sunset. When the sun is low in the sky, there are long shadows and vibrant colors. After the sun sets, the colors continue to glow, then fade and with a brief intermission, are followed by Blue Hour, the time the sky turns vivid blue creating a spectacular background for city photos. 

Blue Hour Photo Suzanne Merritt

These are two very special fleeting, times of day that offer the opportunity to capture dramatic scenes without the use of special filters or effects. They really don't last a full hour so part of the secret is getting ready so when the light shifts you can take full advantage of the opportunity.

Nearly Full Moon This Saturday Night can be photographed during Blue Hour

 During this workshop you will discover:

• The best camera settings for these two special times of day.

• What subjects work best for Golden Hour and Blue Hour.

• How to capture a variety of different qualities of light on reflective surfaces.

• Creative composition techniques that create stunning photos.


How we will work. We will gather at 5:30 and I will give you specific instructions  tips and handouts for the shoot. Round One will be by the Charles River, a spectacular spot for photographing the sun set. I have selected the best spot to capture the long shadows and golden light. 

Golden Hour by the Charles River Suzanne Merritt

Then we will move to a second location and I will give you the second set of instructions for how to take stunning photos during Blue Hour. You will be amazed to discover how easy it is once you know what to look for and how to set up your camera. This images have a magical, look and feel that anyone can capture with the basic information provided during this class.

Notice details that make great silhouettes against the sky.

Whether you are new to the group or have attended many session, I know you will enjoy this new workshop so I hope you will join us. We always have a great time learning new things together.  Tuition for this workshop is $30.00 and you can RSVP right now to save your space.

Photographing people in the golden light. Dramatic long shadows and glow.

 I hope you can make it, I would love to see you there.  All levels welcome. 

Suzanne

P.S. Be sure to allow some extra time for Happy Hour which follows Golden Hour and Blue Hour. We will stop in a local Pub near Copley Square and look at the photos from class and discuss what was learned. 

Blue Hour Reflections Suzanne Merritt

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4

results.name: Fun Photo Double Feature: Stunning Golden Hour & Blue Hour,  Photo Secrets

results.description:
This looks interesting.    I am curious to see how they portray one of Boston's most notorious criminals.

Showtime is 7.  I will be at the theater by 6 and we will head in for seats at 6:30.  The movie will be showing upstairs so we will gather at the tables by the windows at the top of the escalators.

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  Tickets are on sale at Fandango now.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Movie Details:

Release date: September 18, 2015  


Studio: Warner Bros. Pictures       

Director: Scott Cooper

MPAA Rating: N/A

Screenwriter: Mark Mallouk

Starring: Adam Scott, Johnny Depp, Sienna Miller, Kevin Bacon, Juno Temple, Joel Edgerton, Rory Cochrane, Benedict Cumberbatch, Jesse Plemons, Dakota Johnson, Corey Stoll

Genre: Drama, Crime

Official website: BlackMassmovie.com                  

Plot Summary:

In 1970s South Boston, FBI Agent John Connolly (Joel Edgerton) persuades Irish mobster James “Whitey” Bulger (Johnny Depp) to collaborate with the FBI and eliminate a common enemy: the Italian mob. The drama tells the true story of this unholy alliance, which spiraled out of control, allowing Whitey to evade law enforcement, consolidate power, and become one of the most ruthless and powerful gangsters in Boston history.

This is a joint event with the Cards & Conversations meetup group so we don't have a waitlist. Tonight is an open game night -- all card, tile, board and party games are welcome. Be sure to bring your favorite one :) If you rsvp "yes" and then have a change of plans please be sure to update your rsvp ahead of time so that you won't be counted as a "no show" and to allow for other members to attend since we have a limit on attendance. Thank you very much.

Live in the Metrowest area and want to come to our events but they're too far away? Want to make some new friends, eat some good food and play some fun games in the process? Make some time on your calendar for Saturday night because we have the event just for you.

While all games are welcome, here are some suggestions for tonight:

American Mah Jongg -- whether you are a beginner or a seasoned pro, we guarantee that there will be a table (or two) for people to play and mingle.

Cribbage -- a lot of people are picking up this game, because it is so awesome. Do you have a cribbage board? If so, be sure to bring it :)

Sequence -- Have you played this game before? The rules are simple but I warn you that it is quite addicting.

We'll be meeting at the Panera in Waltham. Panera offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a light meal and conversation. The bakery-cafe offers innovative salads and sandwiches, delicious baked goods and healthy frozen shakes.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are Panera. The food is very good, so it will be hard to resist!

Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Note that due to limited space we may place a limit on attendees if too many people sign up (or cancel it if we don't get any at all!)

HOW TO GET THERE

Panera Bread is located at 1100 Lexington Street in Waltham -- in the Shaw's plaza near the corner of Lexington Street and Trapelo Road. Ample parking. Web site: http://www.panera-bos...

results.description:
There is no God. Now what? If this is the only life we have, how does that affect how we lives our lives, how we treat each other, and cope with death. Photographer and filmmaker Chris Johnson introduces us to some of the many voices from his book. In this fascinating documentary — learn the stories behind the book in interviews with some of our greatest thinkers. 

Chris Johnson is a New York-based photographer and filmmaker. He received his undergraduate degree in film production (along with a minor in religious studies) from Concordia University in Montreal, Quebec. His photography has been seen in various outlets, including The New York Times. He has spent the last three years working on the book and film versions of A Better Life, traveling across the United States, Canada, the UK, Ireland, and other countries.
results.name: A Better Life Film Screening

group.name: The Humanist Hub in Harvard Square

results.description:
RSVP FOR TICKETS at https://www.eventbrite.com/e/documentary-screening-with-filmmaker-chris-johnsona-better-life-an-exploration-of-joy-meaning-in-a-tickets-18532974626

* * * 

There is no God. Now what? If this is the only life we have, how does that affect how we lives our lives, how we treat each other, and cope with death. Photographer and filmmaker Chris Johnson introduces us to some of the many voices from his book. In this fascinating documentary — learn the stories behind the book in interviews with some of our greatest thinkers.

* * *
ABOUT THE FILMMAKER: Chris Johnson is a New York-based photographer and filmmaker. He received his undergraduate degree in film production (along with a minor in religious studies) from Concordia University in Montreal, Quebec. His photography has been seen in various outlets, including The New York Times. He has spent the last three years working on the book and film versions of A Better Life, traveling across the United States, Canada, the UK, Ireland, and other countries.
Join us for a screening with the filmmaker, who will be available for a short Q&A following the film. 

* * *


If you can't make it to the screening, but want to hear more from Chris, he will be speaking at the Humanist Hub on Sunday, September 27 at 1:30: https://www.facebook.com/events/1175931322423718/
results.name: Documentary Screening: "Joy & Meaning in a World Without God"

results.description:
The Humanist Hub is sponsoring a screening of Chris Johnson's documentary, "A Better Life: An Exploration of Joy and Meaning in a World Without God" at the Humanist Hub this coming Saturday, September 26 at 7 pm in Cambridge. 

For ticket information, use this link: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/documentary-screening-with-filmmaker-chris-johnsona-better-life-an-exploration-of-joy-meaning-in-a-tickets-18532974626

Our friends at the Humanist Hub will also welcome the filmmaker to speak on Sunday, September 27 at their weekly 1:30 gathering at the Hub. Even if you can't see the film, this promises to be a great opportunity to hear how humanists all over the world are creating meaning in their lives without gods! The Humanist Hub in Cambridge, formerly The Humanist Community at Harvard, welcomes you to their many activities every week. Join their Meet Up to get the full list of options!

The Humanist Hub is on the 4th floor of 30 JFK Street near Harvard Square subway station. There is an elevator to the 4th Floor. Parking in the area is possible via parking garages or on-street parking, but public transit it your best bet.
results.name: A Better Life: Joy and Meaning in a World Without God: Film Screening

results.description:
Hey fellow 20's and 30's, 


Do you want to meet new people who share your values? 
Do you want easily meet interesting new people? 
What's our celebration going to be like (see pictures) 

Join us for our popular Mix & Mingle celebration. The purpose of this Meetup is for you to meet people who are different from you. Discover new communities. 
Discover who else is coming. 

For this event we will be joining one of Boston's most popular nonprofits. 
Learn more:  Boston Volunteers

Space is very limited b/c the room is small. This event will fill up very soon. We'll get lots of the regulars and lots of new members. 

A couple other groups will be joining us including: 

Do you live near Brookline: Brookline Area 20's & 30's Adventurers 

Don't you like to do good: Boston Volunteers

Are you a Foodie: Favorite Boston Restaurants

We will be providing lots and lots of food for you. We will serve the food at close to 7:30, so don't miss it!  

Please bring a 10 bill with you to help cover our costs for the event, Meetup costs, and to provide more volunteer events for you in the future. Please bring a 10. There will be a long line, and we want to keep it moving fast. 


Oh, and by the way, we'll also be providing a drink ticket (good until 8:30) for you. Good for one refreshing and ice-cold spirit to quench your thirst. Complimentary! :) 


What a Hassle-free way to meet new people who share your values. 

We hope you can join us, :) 
Josh and friends

results.description:
Please bring one of the following:   Taurasi, Aglianico del Vulture, Basilicata,  Lacryma Christi (red or white),  Greco di Tufo, or Fiano di Avellino in the $20 - $50 range.

The world's first Rock-Star Winemaker, Pliny the Elder of Ancient Rome,  prized the Aglianico and Greco grapes from Campania and Basilcata above all others. Even today, these wines are considered to be among the very best of Italy, and yet they stand in the very long shadow of Piedmont and Tuscany. 

Let's explore the muscular, powerful, tannic Aglianico, which thrives in the mountains' volcanic soils there. Taurasi, Aglianico del Vulture, and Basilicata are the place-names to look for.  Lacryma Christi red, made from other grapes, would also be a fine inclusion for the evening.


We'll also taste the regions' aromatic, herbaceous, deeply colored white wines of Greco di Tufo, Fiano di Avellino, and Lacryma Christi white, which also rely on the volcanic soils there to convey their unique expressions.


Please plan to spend between $20-$50 for these fine hidden gems.


Tori will be preparing some wonderful food to go with these wines, so please bring $10 to reimburse her, 4 glasses, and your wine in a paper wine bag.
results.name: Campania and Basilicata-- Ancient Rome's Collector Wines

results.description:
Sake is a Japanese alcoholic beverage made from fermented rice.  Often called rice wine, its production is more akin to beer than wine.  Whereas wine involves a one step process fermenting sugar into alcohol, the brewing of sake involves a two step process fermenting starch into sugar into alcohol.

Sake is the national drink of Japan and can be traced back to early 3rd century AD.  It was traditionally produced primarily by the imperial court and large temples and shrines until the 12th century when the general population began manufacturing it. 

Like wine, sake has a diverse range of flavor profiles (e.g. sweet to dry, fruity to floral, bold to elegant, earthy to herbal, etc.) and actually has more .  Sake can be served chilled, room temperature, or heated, depending on the season, quality of sake, and preference.

There are many types of sakes and they can differ based on: type of rice, amount of rice polish, type and amount of water, yeast amount and type, maturation period, as well as the brewer’s skill and style.  Some of the more popular and easily found sakes are listed below with potential pairing profiles (Note you are not limited to just these sakes.  If you want to bring something else please do so):

Junmai – pure with no adjuncts added during production process and rice 30% polished grain.  It is more complex, fuller texture and acidic and pairs well with foods that have more substance (e.g. tempura, pizza, soy based, grilled meats).

Honjozo – brewer’s alcohol is added during fermentation and rice 30% polished away.  It is lighter and less complex than Junmai and less sensitive to temperature variations.  Pairs better with lighter food items.

Ginjo – adjuncts added in and rice used in production has at least 40% of its grain polished away.  Delicate and lighter and pairs better with lighter food items.

Daiginjo –  adjuncts added in and rice used in production has at least 50% of its grain polished way.  Similar to Ginjo it pairs better with lighter food items.

WHAT TO BRING:

Basically bring 411 – 4 drinking vessels, 1 bottle of sake, 1 food item.  Details and specifics just below.

Sake:

Bring a 720 ml bottle of sake; this is almost equivalent in size to the 750 ml wine bottle we are familiar with. 

Food:

Please bring a food item to share that will also pair well with sake.  Beyond Japanese food, sake actually can pair quite well with a variety of items from seafood to grilled meats to cheeses and pasta.  Foods with umami (savory) are excellent with sake too.  So bring something interesting and let's experiment.

Drinking Vessel:

Please bring 4 drinking vessels for the sake.  The vessels can be anything you prefer such as wine glasses, mugs, or more traditional vessels like ceramic sake cups (choko) or even wood cups (masu).  Wine glasses actually work quite well with sake.  It just needs to be able to hold 2 ounces of sake well, so leave the big glasses at home.

Sake is a complex beverage so this even is about experimenting, learning, and having fun.
results.name: Sake Tasting

results.description:
Tim has made the most of his time in Boston on the various walks and adventures of our group!  So please join us and wish Tim farewell the Active, Healthy and Social way by walking through Back Bay, Chinatown, Beacon Hill and Faneuil Hall/Northend area.


*This will not be your usually bar/lounge crawl, its kinda eclectic. No sneakers: if you wear sneakers you will not be allow in at Revere Hotel & Liberty Hotel. 

These are the Bars and Lounges we will be hitting up:

- Rattle Snake Bar & Grill


-Revere Hotel rooftop bar/lounge

-Liberty Hotel at the Alibi

-Red Hat in Beacon Hill (one of the oldest establishment in Boston)

-Lastly we will end up at Tia's waterfront

or last top is Mike's in the Northend for a Cannoli.  I don't think we should let Tim go back to Kentucky without having a cannoli's at Mike's and a latte at Caffe Vittoria

***please don't drink and drive.  Take public transportations.  We hope to see you out Sat night.

results.description:
Let's dance salsa!

Saturday Night Salsa is Boston's biggest salsa dance party on Saturdays featuring salsa dancing and lessons with Salsa y Control, an amazing venue filled with 300+ welcoming salsa dancers, an inexpensive parking garage next door, and public transport on Mass Ave. (Red Line, Buses 1, 64 etc.) one block away!

9:00-10:00pm:  Beginner & Intermediate. Salsa Lessons
10:00-2am: Dance Party * No Partner Required

Lets meet 15 minutes before the dance lesson at 8:45pm at (facing the stage) at the right side of the stage.

There are some tables alongside the wall. These tables are typically first come, first serve, so if we all arrive at the same time and early, we can occupy these tables.

I will make some Meetup signs and try to post them at these tables.  These tables can serve as our meeting point through out the night.

I also have some neon/glow-in-the-dark bracelets and necklaces that I plan to wear and pass out to members of the group so we can recognize each other more easily.

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  This is an actual event, not an advertisement. 

Please be on time! If you arrive late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to recognize members of the group from the crowds.

This should be a super fun event and a super friendly event for salsa beginners and the advanced dancers.


I am really looking forward to enjoying this event as part of the group.

Wear comfortable shoes!

Joana

******************************************************************************************************************************

Event Details

Beginners Very Welcome

No partner required

$12 - Admission includes lesson and party

Dress Code: Smart Casual to Elegant (No ball caps, no work boots, etc.)

Beer, Wine, Mixed Drinks, etc. available at Bar

Music format: 65% salsa, 25% bachata, 10% merengue/cha cha

***********************************
Driving Directions: Take Storrow or Memorial Drive to River St. (where the two gas stations are), then a right on Mass Ave, a right on Pearl St (where FootLocker and Putnam Furniture is), and your first right on Green St.

Parking: There is a large, inexpensive ($1.50/hr)parking garage right next door - you can't miss it!

Walking Directions (from Red Line's Central Stop): From Mass Ave take a left on Prospect St then a left on Green St. It is a one minute walk.

Please note that the Night Salsa parties are 21+.

* Don't forget your ID!

http://www.havanaclubsalsa.com/salsa_saturdays.shtml
results.how_to_find_us: Right side of the stage at 8:45pm sharp!
results.name: Lets Dance Salsa!  at the Havana Club in Central Square! Lesson Included!

results.description:
The Puritans who founded the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1630 were driven by a commitment to their religious ideals and beliefs. But it was Scottish prisoners of war who did the dirty work, building the tools for a new colony as the flow of material goods from England dwindled. In keeping with our Food and Drink of 17th-century Boston theme, we'll discover how workers at the Saugus Iron Works ate, drank, and lived.

Curtis Wright, Lead Ranger, will give the tour, which includes a hearth cooking demonstration in the forge.


Neil Wright, industrial archaeologist from Lincolnshire and PHB Trustee, will talk about talk about the technology and food brought from Stuart England.


Free but you must register by clicking here.
results.name: Fueling New England's Iron Age: Food at the Saugus Iron Works

results.description:
On Saturday, September 26, the Coolidge Corner Theatre will present its annual midnight screening of Serenity, the feature-length follow-up to Joss Whedon's short-lived television series, Firefly.

Proceeds from this tenth-anniversary screening will benefit Joss Whedon's favorite charity, Equality Now, which works to end violence and discrimination against women and girls around the world through the mobilization of public pressure. Bring canned goods to exchange for raffle tickets to win sweet Serenity swag!

We'll meet at nearby JP Licks (311 Harvard Street in Brookline) at 10:45 PM for ice cream and then make our way to the cinema line. Join us at the ice cream parlor or in line at the theater — as long as you have your ticket, you're guaranteed a seat! Find more details and purchase your movie tickets in advance for $15 + $2.50 fee by clicking the movie time on this page:

http://www.coolidge.org/films/serenity

Add in the time for raffles, and the MBTA will likely have stopped running by the time the film gets out, so plan your travel accordingly.


More details about CSTS in general are at https://www.facebook.com/CSTSBoston
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the Meetup sign!
results.name: Can't Stop the Serenity 2015

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to five of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Wildcat D, Wildcat A, Carter Dome, South Carter, and Middle Carter. We will use the Wildcat Ridge Trail and the Carter-Moriah Trail to do this traverse from the south to the north. We will return to our cars after the Carters along the Imp Trail. This route has steep rock scrambles and exposed ledges. Along the way we will be able to stop at the AMC's Carter Notch Hut to grab some snacks and refill our water.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 16.3 miles and climb about 6,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 11 hours 30 minutes to complete. This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/9-Carter-Dome-4832--15-Middle-Carter-4610--19-South-Carter-4430 


http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/20-Mt-Wildcat-4422--40-Wildcat-D-Peak-4050

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.289&lon=-71.176#.VVQa1XD3aK0


=== What to Bring ===


Use this link for a list of items needed for most three-season day hikes:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf 

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Nineteen Mile Brook Trail lot that is located on the east side of a Route 16 north of the Mount Wasgington Auto Road. According to Google Maps this spot is about 178 miles from Boston and it will take about 3 hours to drive there. Since that is where we will end our trip we will leave a few cars there and drive to the start.

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.
results.name: Volunteer and serve breakfast at the New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
Croiss training involves fitting in as many croissants as is compatible with the length of the ride.

The days are getting shorter and the opportunities for a century at a relaxed pace are dwindling. Join me for a leisurely tour by the scenic route from Boston to Providence and back. At least two bakeries and a final stop at JP Licks in Jamaica Plain are in the plan. Average moving pace will be ~ 12 mph and total pace should be 9 mph to avoid getting back after dark. But nobody will be left behind.

Just remember, a hundred miles is a hundred (100) miles.   Once we are 50 miles out, it's going to be 50 miles back.

In a nutshell, the route is

Emerald Necklace to Needham to Dover (16 miles)

Medfield, Franklin (30 miles)

Diamond Hill Reservoir (45 miles) - one of my favorite views

Pawtucket, East Providence, L'Artisan bakery (53 miles)

Return via Foxboro (75), Norwood, Dedham, Jamaica Plain (JP Licks!) at 95 and home for an even 100.

 Winds look favorable - low in the morning, and picking up from the SE as the day goes on.   Starting temps around 50, rising to 70 - maybe a two layer day.


See you soon!
results.name: Croiss training ride Boston <-> Providence

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

results.description:
Tony, Joe and I enjoyed this worldwide fundraiser last year and had a blast! We're hoping to get a bigger showing of local scooter riders this year. For those who are not aware of this charity ride, this is long-standing, annual worldwide charity event for custom motorcycle and scooter riders to help raise funds for research on a cure for prostate cancer. We were invited last year to join the custom riders to make a stronger showing here in Boston, and we were honored to be part of it!

Please consider joining our group's team which will be participating once again in the Boston ride and we're hoping to raise at least $500 towards this cause! Please be advised that this a special themed ride which requires registered riders to wear their "Sunday bests" this includes; suits, sport coats, ties, fancy vests, etc., hence the name "gentleman's ride". Take a look at the website for more info. It really is a lot of fun! This year they are encouraging riders to invite a guest to ride "back seat" so remember to invite your friend or special someone to join in the fun!

If you can not ride with us, we need you to help spread the word about this awesome event so we can grow our team and present strongly as a group. Those who register for with a $12 donation can get a cool patch commemorating your involvement. Pretty sweeet.

This year, I hope to participate in the entire ride, which begins on the North Shore, continues through metro Boston and winds up just South of the City, specific details TBD. The ride is safe for smaller motorcycles and scooters because the route is off-highway and the speed limit does not go over 40 mph. FInish line location will be added to this announcement as it is posted on the ride website, I'll include it here as soon as possible.

Let's have some fun, ride with other motorcycle and scooter enthusiasts and look dapper for a great cause! Regards, Andrew D.

results.description:
This 30-mile loop includes my three favorite gravel paths/roads that don't require a mountain bike. In other words, no technical sections, and only 5 miles total. I do this on my road bike with narrow tires, but some folk might be more comfortable on a hybrid. I wouldn't recommend a mountain bike unless you are in very good shape, otherwise it will be hard to keep up with us on the roads.

The first 4 miles are on the Minuteman Bikeway into Bedford. Next 4 are the Reformatory Branch Trail, which is a flat gravel trail (with occasional sandy spots) through forests. Bathroom & water-bottle refill in Concord Center, then normal roads out to mile 18. Next comes a one-mile section of gravel road in Wayland with gorgeous views, followed by a quick stop to admire PonyHenge. The third and final gravel section is at mile 23. This is a narrow single-track, but smooth, straight, and very short. The last 6 miles loop around the Cambridge Reservoir, climb up Spring St, and down to Lexington Center.

Here's the map and cuesheet: http://ridewithgps.com/routes/10555180

When: 
Let's meet up at 9:45 am and be ready to start at 10:00 am. Aiming to be back by 1:30 pm.

Where: 
We start out in Lexington Center, which has free parking in the Depot lot on Sundays. Meet by the water fountain at the entrance to the lot, right on the bikeway.

Who: 
You need to be okay with a 12-15 mph pace. We will wait for everyone at the top of major hills and at confusing intersections, but please don't sign up if you can't keep at least a 12 mph average pace with relatively few stops.

What's required: 
* Road or hybrid bike in good repair 
* Bike helmet 
* At least one full large water bottle (you can refill along the way) 
* Spare tube, and air

What's recommended: 
* Basic repair tools 
* Snack 
* Cell phone
results.name: 30 mile loop with 5 miles of gravel

results.description:
In addition to a September Meetup, lets get together to visit the latest exhibit at the American Textile History Museum!

The American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Massachusetts is proud to present Wonder of Wool: Ancient Fiber to Modern Marvel, on view May 20 through December 21, 2015.

Wool is one of the most commonly used fibers in the world and easily the most misunderstood. Wonder of Wool: Ancient Fiber to Modern Marvel takes a fascinating look at the significance of sheep and wool in our culture and our everyday lives, shattering myths and giving visitors a new understanding and appreciation of this fabulous fiber. See more at: http://www.athm.org/museum_exhibition/wonder-of-wool-ancient-fiber-to-modern-marvel/#sthash.nL528sIv.dpuf

There will be no group dues but you will need to purchase a ticket. 

$10 for adults 17 and older.
$8 for seniors (65 and older), children 6 – 16, and college students with ID. Purchase tickets here: https://athm.yapsody.com/event/index/11210/athm-admission
OR
Wait until the day we go and use this coupon to save $2: http://www.athm.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Web-Coupon.pdf

There are a lot of places around the museum if we want to get lunch after! Cobblestones is a favorite of mine! http://cobblestonesoflowell.com/

REGISTER AT: http://ecta27.camp7.org/event-2043760

Join Board Members Joe Sandulli and Dan Mayer on a guided tree identification walk around the Ipswich River Watershed Association "Riverbend" campus and neighboring properties.

We will begin at the Riverbend parking lot and will first explore the trails on this publicly accessible property. Next we will move onto the private trails adjacent to Riverbend.

During the walk, Joe and Dan will point out significant riparian and upland trees and their notable characteristics for identification. This short walk of about .75 miles is easily accessible to walkers of all ages and abilities. Leashed dogs are allowed. The walk should take about an hour.

Dan Mayer, president of Mayer Tree Service, studied arboriculture and forestry at the Stockbridge School of Agriculture, is a Massachusetts Certified Arborist and has been involved in the tree care industry since 1984. Dan joined ECTA as a board member in 2012.

REGISTER AT: http://ecta27.camp7.org/event-2043760
