results.description:
Come on out and join the Inline Club of Boston for our weekly Sunday Morning City Skate!

Every Sunday morning May through September (weather permitting) we meet up at JFK Park in Cambridge for a 6 to 8 mile skate through the streets of Cambridge, Somerville and parts of Boston. Destinations vary widely and may include city neighborhoods, City Squares such as Harvard and Kendall, Harvard and MIT campuses and bike paths on both sides of the river.

This is designed as an entry level city skate so there are some points prospective participants should keep in mind. 

We do skate in the streets so you will need to be comfortable on your skates in light city traffic. We do try to keep to the more quiet roads but traffic is never completely predictable.

You should have good stopping skills. The city does present a wide variety of obstacles and the ability to control your speed and stop is important.

It is important that you are comfortable negotiating minor road obstacles such as curbs, sewer grates, sand or dirt and substandard pavement.

We do periodically go down small hills.

We recommend that you wear all protective gear. Most of the things out here are pretty hard!

Of course we do our best to minimize these issues but it is never possible to miss them all.

If this sounds like something for you and you have some more questions or need more info please feel free to contact Neil Wetzler at [masked] and we will respond as quickly as possible.

We meet up at JFK park around 10 and depart at 10:30. As stated, the skate is generally 6 to 8 miles in length and will last between an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour an a half. Most Sundays we gather afterwards for coffee and treats or lunch and to talk about our skating adventures. The skate is always announced Saturday morning on the ICB mailing list, Facebook page and Meetup page.

Even if you don’t feel you are up to this skate yet please feel free to come and meet the group any Sunday morning. If this is your first Sunday Skate please introduce yourself to the skate leader and other skaters. We were all new to this once and will be very happy to welcome you to the skate. Even if you’re not up to skating with us quite yet please feel free to come by and meet the group.

We also run a Midweek on the Minuteman skate that may be more to your liking. You can meet some of the group and develop the skills that will get you out on a Sunday!

We hope to meet you soon!

Getting to JFK Park: Take the T (Red Line) to Harvard Square, or if driving, you can park on most streets since Cambridge’s resident-only parking restriction is lifted on Sundays. We normally park on Memorial Drive (just to the West of JFK park) or Mt. Auburn St, and walk/skate over to the park.

Check out the skills necessary for this event in our Skate Skills page.

Don’t forget to sign up for our mailing list to receive updates about this and other ICB events!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at JFK Park in Cambridge by the fountain, about 100 yards from the intersection
results.name: Sunday Morning Social Skate

results.description:
Join Date-Able Single Members of multiple meetup groups [as listed below] for our first Mini Golf event!  Get to know singles who are available to date with mini golf and ice cream! Yes, you read it correctly! Your $6 includes 18 holes of mini golf and ice cream. This is one of my favorite mini golf courses, partly due to the ice cream. This is quite a deal. They open at 11am and have agreed to open early @ 10:45am so we can start early if we have at least 2 dozen people joining us . We will be meeting shortly before they open so we can be the first ones on the golf course and enjoy ourselves.

We'll meet and check-in @ 10:30am and do introductions as we form groups based on who likes to follow the rules, who likes to bend the rules, and who likes to be footloose and fancy-free.  We'll mostly be interacting with our group members and those immediately in front of or behind us.  As each group finishes we'll enjoy some ice cream and do some more introductions and get to know each other a little more.  Afterwards, if anyone is interested, we can grab a bite to eat, either breakfast or lunch; there are a couple of options in walking distance very close by.

This is a multi-group event as listed below.  Please do not double or triple RSVP.  It may co$t ya.

Social Fun: www.meetup.com/socialfun

South Shore Dining Out Meetup Group: www.meetup.com/ssdomg

South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club: www.meetup.com/socialnetwork-1414

South of Boston, Norwood Singles Social Events/Dating Meetup: http://www.meetup.com/Norwood-Singles-Social-Events-and-Dating-Meetup/

We are asking each group to have a co-host to help with attendance (for your particular group), and with getting groups organized and keeping the peace.  (We don't want to be a bad example to the kids who may be golfing behind us, do we.*wink*)  Groups without a co-host will be limited to 6 participants, including the Host.

Please keep an open mind and be open to meeting singles who might be interested in dating you or who may know someone who may be interested in dating you!  Given the various age groups of the different meetup groups please consider joining us if you are not near retirement age.  (Suggested age range for this event is 21-59.  There will be other all-ages singles events in the future as I will mix them up.)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Date-Able Singles Mini Golf
Sunday, September 27th @ 10:30am -1pm
Pine Meadows Mini Golf
Main Street
Route 18
Next to Jiffy Lube (1419 Main Street)
South Weymouth
(No phone on-site.)

Meeting Location: Please meet along the fence near the building in the parking lot side.  We are expecting over 2 dozen people so please be mindful of everyone's safety.

Organizer(s): Angela & Chris / Each Group needs an Event Co-Host who will be in charge of Attendance for their Group.

Min/Max: We are requesting at least 10 Yes RSVPs among all groups (excluding the Host) at least one week prior to the event.  Each group will start with a max of 6 which will be increased to 10 once we have an Event Co-Host in place and a WaitList.  The maximum total for this event is 40 people between all groups and I will adjust the max in each group accordingly 4-5 days prior to the event.  

Guests: None at this time.

Cost: $6 for 18 holes of mini golf and ice cream

Fee: Since this is an event for multiple meetup groups and they all have different policies for fees and such, there will be no fees for today's event.  However, if you belong to a group that does have fees or voluntary donations I will gladly accept it and pass it along.

Cash Only Policy: Please adhere to our Group's cash only policy. Please bring small bills for event fees.

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 7pm on Saturday, September 26th.  You may change your RSVP up until 2 hours prior to the event, however, anyone who is a Yes who doesn't attend or notify us within 24 hours will be considered a no-show.  Who wants to date a no-show, LOL?!!?

Inclement Weather: Rains will probably cancel. (We will do our best to notify everyone around or shortly after the RSVP Deadline or by 9am on Saturday if this is cancelled.) **I spoke w/ the owner and overnight rains are not a problem. If it is rainy when I get up I will call the owner to check to make sure we are still on. If this event is cancelled I will do my best to email the Yes RSVPs by 9:30am on Sunday. Plan to mini golf though because the rain is supposed to fall in the early morning hours. We are the first ones on the course and by meeting at 10:30 we can check everyone in and get groups figured out so we can have fun mini golfing.**

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions: Please use mapquest.com for door-to-door directions.

Overview: Located on Route 18 just north of the intersection of Route 58 w/ Factory Paint on the corner. Located diagonally across from Extra Space Storage and the Commuter Rail.

From Route 18NB/Abington and points south: Follow Route 18 into Weymouth. Once you pass the intersection of Route 58 w/ Factory Paint on the corner you will travel thru one set of lights pas the T and Storage place. It will be on your left shortly thereafter.

From Route 18SB/Weymouth and points north: Follow Route 18 south past the South Shroe Hospital, 99 restaurant, and SouthField (former Naval Air Station). I believe this is located just south of Main Street Grille. It will be on your right next to Jiffy Lube. If you see the Storage place and/or the T and/or a set of lights you have just passed it.


Please Note: All of my events are for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of that.

Looking forward to meeting you - ma'a salaame!!

I'll bring one net. If someone lets me know they're bringing another net, then i'll up the attendee limit.

We'll play intermediate-advanced sand doubles.  Intermediate means that you have the skills and experience required to pass, set and hit 80% of the time. If you don't bring an A-game, you can expect to receive advice on technique.

If there are folks who want to play women's height net, we can add 10-foot lines.

You might want to bring a beach chair, bug spray, and water.

We give priority to regular goers and that means your reservation status may be changed.  If you attend this meetup from the waitlist, you will not be able to play.  I regret any frustration that this may cause.

Looking forward to seeing everyone!

See you on the beach, Matt

results.description:
Meet at Jane & Tim’s 102 Litchfield St., Brighton, park in Star Market (on Western Ave.) lot,  at 11AM sharp, we will practice a few  songs then shuttle up to line up for the parade.


Parade begins at 1PM, we walk the 2 miles down Brighton Avenue to Washington Street and end at a party at Oak Square.  We will be singing, dancing and giving out beads – asking people to join us singing!

We will have a decorated van (12 seats) so you can rest if needed on the parade route.

Note: There will be plenty of room to ride in the van but we need lots of lively, walking Minstrels in front of the van.  Wear your new Minstrel Tee Shirt!!

The van will leave the house around 11:30-45, all sound equipped and decorated. 

This is a new one for us , I hope many of you can make it, we'll make a big splash and ripples will move into people's hearts!

Thanks,  Jane and Tim

.

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting. ------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

results.description:
This is one of the simplest forms of healing and self-development system that exists!

By opening and strengthening the energy channels of the body, it is possible to channel healing reiki energy to yourself and others – just by intention!

Kundalini means ‘coiled one’ and is known as latent female energy believed to lie coiled at the base of the spine.  In yogic theory, it is a primal energy, or shakti, located at the base of the spine. Different spiritual traditions teach methods of "awakening" kundalini for the purpose of reaching spiritual enlightenment. The Yoga Upanishads describe Kundalini as lying "coiled" at the base of the spine, represented as either a goddess or sleeping serpent waiting to be awakened. In modern commentaries, Kundalini has been called an unconscious, instinctive or libidinal force, or "mother energy or intelligence of complete maturation".

Kundalini awakening is said to result in deep meditation, enlightenment and bliss. This awakening involves the Kundalini physically moving up the central channel to reach within the Crown Chakra at the top of the head. Many systems focus on the awakening of Kundalini through meditation, pranayama breathing, and the practice of asana and chanting of mantras. In physical terms, one commonly reports the Kundalini experience to be a feeling of electric current running along the spine.

For our purposes we will be opening and awakening your energy centers and channels to gain access to and allow your kundalini to ‘rise’ up and out of your body cleaning and clearing out all that no longer serves your highest good.

During this workshop you will:

• Learn what Kundalini Reiki is

• History of Kundalini Reiki

• Learn about the 3 Levels of Attunements

• Learn how using Kundalini can benefit you and others

• Enjoy a guided meditative experience  & receive Level 1 Kundalini Reiki Attunement

Cost $40 - 2 hour workshop includes manual, level 1 attunement in person, then levels 2 & 3 via remote session, and a certificate (via mail) after your 3rd attunement is complete.

Your 2nd & 3rd attunements will be scheduled and be done via remote connection at a time convenient for you.  There will be at least 10 days between each attunement to allow for the integration of energy as needed.

Nicol is a Certified Usui, Lightarian and Kundalini Reiki Master.

No prior knowledge or attunements are required to receive and use this empowering energy!  Upon receiving your 3rd attunment, you will be a Kundalini Reiki Master and will be certified to attune others.

www.essencehealing.net
results.name: Kundalini Reiki Workshop and Level 1 Attunement

results.description:
The weather is still cooperating and we should take advantage of it! 

Join us this month at Danehy Dog Park in Cambridge. With plenty of off-street parking and a fully enclosed fence, it is a truly a gem of a park just outside of Boston.

Feel free to leave a comment about the park if you're familiar.

As always, please be mindful of the weather to make for safe travels. If the weather turns for the worst, there will be no rain date and we'll just reschedule the following month.


Hope to see you there. Tell all your corgi friends!

Dexter Update: A few weeks back I sent a note to all of you in assistance for a member who was looking for assistance in placing their corgi, Dexter. I'm happy to report that Dexter has moved to a twelve acre apple orchard and horse farm in NH! He has a two-year old corgi brother who he gets along with really well and they spend their days running around the farm and "helping" in ways that only corgis can. Alerica wants to thank everyone who reached out and let the group know that the family appreciates your concern. It was a very difficult and deeply sad process, but in the end they found the best outcome for their family and for Dexter.

-Kevin

Massive Bowling

Pool/Skeeball/Shuffleboard

Extravaganza!

Hey everyone!

It's time again for our big monthly bowling event at Kings! We always have a great time and we always pack the place. If you've attended before, you know THIS EVENT IS AWESOME, RIGHT?! Of course you do!

FAQ:

results.description:
Have you heard that the Humanist Hub has a secular Sunday school: teaching, ethics, mindfulness, and community to the kids of non-religious and interfaith families?

We do! The program is called the Humanist Learning Lab and we’re excited to share the details of our first big meeting of the year -- this Sunday from 12pm to 1pm -- along with our first Learning Lab video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QeKZREcOw38


The Humanist Learning Lab existed as a very small pilot program for the past 3 years but is now expanding dramatically since we hired Nick Bohl, an educator and multimedia YouTube artist, to be our first full time teacher and coordinator. Nick’s work is being supervised by Dr. Erik Gregory, the psychologist-in-residence at the Humanist Hub and by a volunteer team of top scholars at Harvard and beyond in developmental moral psychology and related topics. Here is what Nick and the team have come up with so far:

Children have incredible minds: exploratory, inventive, and compassionate minds. There is an inquisitive spirit in young people that (if your childhood was anything like ours) often runs into various obstacles along the way of growing up. There are a thousand and one ways children are told the meaning of their lives instead of being encouraged to make their own. Why is it we aren’t taught critical thinking skills in school? Why don’t we learn what a compassionate exchange of ideas looks like from a young age?

This year we will build a program that does just that. We want to empower the child to ask her own big questions, and offer her a toolkit to try and answer them. We want to tell kids less of what to think, and explore more how to think.

We’ll be putting together interesting prompts every month to explore topics from personal identity, community, all the way to the biosphere and the cosmos, and we’re going to encourage the kids to explore these topics in their own creative way, developing an expressive ritual that brings an incentive to their own internal process. As they do we want to emphasize critical thinking skills, compassion, and finding their own joy in learning.

We’re very excited our first one hour session, this Sunday September 27th from noon to 1pm, where anyone interested can stop by and participate without commitment. It will be a really fun session and afterwards, those who wish can have their children stay for an additional session from 1:30 to 3:00, while parents can stay for our very popular Sunday Speak Series. If you’re interested in helping us put together our learning environment, you could check out our gift registry here: https://www.myregistry.com/public/hhlearninglab

Any help is greatly appreciated to create the Hub’s unique teaching and learning environment. If you’d also like to make a cash donation you can do so at <a>www.humanisthub.org.</a>

You can register your child for the Learning Lab online here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1LAwUu8VthhMMimUQuOoY4_gMbTxUtAr2peC_-aLy4zg/viewform

If you have any questions or would just like to say hi, feel free to email Nick, he would be happy to connect with you. You can email him at [masked], or call at[masked] ext. 106.

results.description:
This is the regular meetup on Sundays at noon at Brooklyn Boulders in Somerville.  Meet by the first table/bench thing by the entrance.  Hopefully we'll get a good variety of climbing interests coming so that everyone can follow their climbing passion!

(Credit to Francesco Cardiello for the information below):
BKBS is the gorgeous, new, state-of-the-art climbing gym most convenient to those in the Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville area. Although pricier, it features 60+ feet toproping and lead climbing, a massive 22 x 140 foot bouldering wall (and there's still another upstairs), yoga & fitness classes, a sauna, awesome water fountains that fill your water bottle, a retail store, lounge area, weight room, and a soon to open cafe! There's even a collaborative work space where you can study, work, and climb!  If you are looking for a partner, or just want to get your climb on, join us for a fun time.

FAQ:

How do I get there? BKBS is conveniently located within a 10 minute walk of the Porter Square station. Walk down Somerville Avenue and turn right on Properzi way and head all the way down. It is also very bike accessible. If you drive, you can find the lot at 30 Dane St. It is located next to Artisans Asylum.

Why should I do this meetup? Since BKBS is such a new community (opened in late July 2013) few people have developed regular climbing partners to train and climb with. This is a great opportunity to meet other climbers interested in BKBS. Climbing is an inherently social sport - to toprope and do lead, you need to meet people who are dedicated to climbing. This meetup assures you'll meet a partner to climb with.

What if I haven't climbed before? First off, don't be intimidated. Everyone started somewhere. If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the Learn the Ropes class. More info can be found here: http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before using the walls. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need? You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time? Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): Day Pass - $25 (Students $18)
10 Pack - $200 (Students $169)

RENTALS: Shoes - $5
Harness - $5
Chalk Bag - $2
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
WHAT: A SoulCollage introduction for newcomers--or a refresher for those already practicing SoulCollage. Let's get our revitalized community off the ground!


If there's interest, we can continue to make SoulCollage cards from 3-5 p.m. (immediately after this workshop).  

WHEN: Sunday, September 27, from 1 to 3 p.m.


WHERE: The Braintree Community Art Center, 1969 Washington St., Braintree, MA 02184. See directions at end.


We'll be in a large, bright, open room on the first floor. The Center has restrooms and free parking. There are restaurants and stores--including a good Michaels--nearby!

WHAT SHOULD I BRING? Everything will be supplied. If cards in progress that you'd like to work on--feel free to bring them. But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine; we'll have plenty to go around. Bring a beverage and a snack, if you like.


COST: $20 for the workshop, plus $5 for tools and a packet of supplies that you get to keep (total $25). At this writing, BCAC is still setting up its online registration/payment system, so you can pay when you arrive with a check, cash (no coins), or PayPal. Need an ATM? Ask; I live nearby and can direct you to one.  


---->FOR NEWCOMERS: You'll receive everything you need to dive into SoulCollage. You'll go home with your first few cards--as many as you care to make--along with lots of info to help you continue on your own (or with us at future gatherings).


---->FOR THOSE SEEKING A REFRESHER: If you're already making SoulCollage cards, come anyway. I'll provide some prompts and ideas for deepening your practice.


RSVPs/CANCELLATIONS: The RSVP list is our headcount for the day. If you plan to attend, RSVP "yes" so you'll receive all Meetup notifications. If your plans change, switch your RSVP to "no" by 24 hours in advance. If you cancel within 24 hours (or RSVP "yes" and don't show up), you'll need to pay $25 anyway to help cover our costs for the day. You'll receive an extra supply packet next time you attend.

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

DIRECTIONS:

For those who know the area: The BCAC is about 3.5 miles south of South Shore Plaza on the same road (Route 37). It's a two-story white house with a big sign in the front yard.


--From Route 93: From either direction: Take Exit 6. Turn left off ramp. This is Route 37. Pass mall on left. Follow Route 37 through several intersections (about 3.5 miles) to BCAC on right, just before Holbrook town line. Street name changes several times; just follow signs for Route 37. 


--By T: Take the Red Line to Braintree; grab a cab at station (someone else can probably give you a ride back after).

--From Route 3: Exit on Union Street.. Pass T station on left. Follow Union to end at Washington Street (facing Thayer Academy). Turn LEFT on Washington, then immediately RIGHT on Central. Follow Central two blocks to end. Turn LEFT on Franklin (Route 37). Follow Route 37 for about 2.5 miles to BCAC on right, just before Holbrook town line. Street name changes several times; just follow signs for Route 37.


Really hope to see you there!
results.name: Gather for a SoulCollage Introduction/Refresher Workshop

results.description:
Ever feel like your life is moving along fine and then you enter into unchartered territory. It could be a new job, a move, or maybe a traumatic event that sends you flopping and wiggling around like a

Fish out of Water.

Life hands us different experiences, ranging from extremely difficult to ultimate happiness with each path being unique to us. That is why this Four-Part Workshop is designed to give you the tools to let go of whatever is blocking you to creating the future you desire. 

These Workshops will Cover:

·  Learning how to purge your thoughts

·  Quieting your Mind

·  Experience several Meditation Techniques & find the right one for you

·  Using Gratitude & Forgiveness to create Joy

·  Discover the art of Journaling

·  Finding your Life’s Purpose

·  Expanding your Comfort Zone

·  Energy/Space Clearing

·  Using EFT, IET & other Modalities to Raise you Energy

These workshops will be taught by two experienced instructors:

Bev Gersteinholds a M.S. degree in Psychology

and a B.S. in Education. She provided crisis intervention as a therapist and director of a local hotline. In recent years, she began a spiritual journey and is a Spiritual Therapist, Reiki Master/Teacher & Certified Life Coach.

Ellen Sklaver holds a B.S. degree in Personality  Psychology. She been a Motivational Coachfor  Coach/Teacher for The North-of- Boston Law of Attraction Meet-up  Group since 2010. She is also Certified as a PSYCH-K & Neuro-Linguistic Programming (NLP) Practitioner. 

Improve yourself from the inside out

Ellen:[masked]

Bev:[masked]

results.description:
There is no God. Now what? If this is the only life we have, how does that affect how we lives our lives, how we treat each other, and cope with death. Photographer and filmmaker Chris Johnson introduces us to some of the many voices from his book. In this fascinating documentary — learn the stories behind the book in interviews with some of our greatest thinkers.


Chris Johnson is a New York-based photographer and filmmaker. He received his undergraduate degree in film production (along with a minor in religious studies) from Concordia University in Montreal, Quebec. His photography has been seen in various outlets, including The New York Times. He has spent the last three years working on the book and film versions of A Better Life, traveling across the United States, Canada, the UK, Ireland, and other countries

results.description:
THE SCENE: To be clear, this is the Lexington Common in the center of town.  I imagine Lexington has many greens.  Well, this is the greenest of the greens.  Hookers Green (although maybe that refers to another Common).  I imagine everyone's seen this green so it goes without description, since if I tell you it has a covered bridge and a waterfall you probably won't believe me.  Also, when we've painted there before across the street is fine, as well, if you prefer.

STATS (1 to 5 with 5 best)

Distance to car:4

Parking availability:5


Bathroom availability:5


Accessibility:5


Artistic appeal:3


RSVP POLICY: ***NOTE THAT THIS EVENT IS SUBJECT TO CANCELLATION IF THERE ARE 3 OR FEWER ARTISTS RSVPd.  SO CHECK YOUR INBOX OR THIS CALENDAR THE DAY OF THE EVENT***


SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS:None


WHERE TO MEET*: At the posted time, with 15 minute leeway for late-comers.  On the green is fine, as is across the street though we may not see one another.

DIRECTIONS:Lexington MA center.

results.description:
Visit the only (so far) cohousing neighborhood in Boston proper, close to the T and the Jamaicaway bike route. Discover why people love living together in sustainable community, blending privacy and neighborly connections, your own kitchen with regular common meals. Meet cohousers young and old, tour the extensive Common House and yard, and map your path to community living. Learn about current and future openings to rent and buy in community.

https://sites.google.com/site/jpcohousinginternet/_/rsrc/1408642841004/config/customLogo.gif?revision=9

This tour repeats: the second Saturday at 2 PM, and the fourth Sunday at 10 AM. Be sure to check the date for the one you are RSVPing to.

About JP Cohousing

We are delighted to have you over to our virtual home! Cohousing is more than just a house-- it's a way of living that makes it easy for you to meet neighbors, make friends, find playmates for the kids, attend parties, or find a movie group. We are situated in the artistic Brookside area of the socially and environmentally-conscious neighborhood of Jamaica Plain in Boston.

In addition to individual fully-equipped units, cohousing members share and enjoy many large common areas because living in cohousing means valuing a sense of community. Our shared facilities include a huge dining hall where we host dinners, parties, and social events; a cozy living room where we show movies and host various clubs; a toddler room for young kids; a rumpus room with exercise equipment, ping-pong and a home theater; office space and meeting room; a laundry room; a large indoor bike storage area; and craft studios. Truly, living in cohousing offers the best of city living, bringing together a diverse and vibrant group of people who value individuality and a sense of community.


Learn more at www.jpcohousing.org
results.how_to_find_us: JP cohousing members will welcome you for one of their regular tours. Be sure to RSVP in advance.
results.name: Tour Jamaica Plain Cohousing (Boston)

results.description:
Come join Women's Lodge for their Fall Equinox Circle at the UKTS wood-burning Finnish sauna** on Furnace Pond in Pembroke on Sunday September 27th from 2:30 pm to 6:30 pm!  

Our Divination this year is calling us, as a community, to a year of transmutation---to a greater level of service in the world while strengthening our individual spiritual practice. Sedna invites us to shed our old victim stories and claim our true selves as women of power. Snake invites us to face our fear of change, shed our skins of habit and birth the magician within us.  And the Gift of Stones invites us to remember the stone footprint of the ancient goddess temples within our beings.

In Preparation for our Equinox Gathering:  We invite you to find an egg-shaped stone.....take some quiet time to sit with your stone....to listen within to your own Sedna story......to speak your victim story(ies) into your stone.....to bring your stone to be held tenderly in the snake nest of our circle....
  We are Inviting you to join us.....as we learn the transforming magic of our Sedna altar, cleanse in the healing waters of sauna & lake, and begin our year-long pilgrimage of releasing the victim archetype within....and 
birthing a greater level of responsibility to service in the world---beyond ceremony----transmuting oppression of women and our beloved Gaia...... 
RSVP: Your RSVP is very helpful in our planning....please email Nouri Newman [masked] to let us know you are coming!
  Please plan to arrive between 1:30 and 2:oo pm for registration. After registration come to the lake with your "sauna stuff"....egg-shaped stone....and ritual offering.  Please plan to be at our lake-side altar...all settled in.... by 2:15 so that we might begin our circle together at 2:30 pm. 
For the Sauna you will need to bring:• A bathing suit for swimming (optional in the sauna)

 . Towel and wash cloth • Plenty of water/water bottle for hydration
 . Felted or washable hat, or head wrapping towel  • Shampoo & other toiletries (as desired)
The sauna house has a changing room with a shower.


Please also bring: 
 . your egg-shaped stone . drums & rattles as desired
 . blanket/portable chair for sitting outdoors
 . sunscreen as desired

 . your donation of $15 (more if you can, less if needed) or your pledge of $90 for our year of circles!

 . a potluck dish to share--perhaps made from your garden...a delicious/beautiful seasonal offering for our Equinox Feast!*
 . special items for our giveaway blanket(optional)
 • sacred objects.....ritual clothing & jewelry 
 *The farmhouse has a kitchen with plenty of  refrigerator space, a stove top and a microwave.

We will meet rain or shine!....surrendering to the weather spirits' offering for us......and indoor ceremony space is available, if needed! 
Before and After:The land and lake are available to Women's Lodge starting at 10 am if you want to come for silent retreat on your own before our circle. 

Our Harvest SuperMoon will be rising at 6:24 pm!...if you so desire, please plan to stay for our joining together around 7 pm...to greet Her...sing to Her and draw down Her power!

Directions: 
UKTS: 83 Suomi Road, Pembroke MA 
www.uktshome.com/sauna.htm 
  Need more information: If you have any questions or concerns, please email Lindsa Vallee at [masked]

**The UKTS sauna was founded by Finnish immigrants over a hundred years ago, offering an authentic wood-burning sauna experience every Saturday from May into November. It is in a secluded woodland setting on the edge of a beautiful clean pond. Because Pam Golden and her family have been part of the sauna community for decades, she was able to arrange for us to have it to ourselves on September 27th.

The sauna is central to traditional Finnish culture, a sanctified environment for cleansing, healing, and life passages from childbirth through dying. Finns believe the sauna is a cure-all for any malady, as the steam cleanses the body of toxins, opens up the lungs and is generally invigorating. Important family and community deliberations are conducted in the sauna, with guidelines for feeding the spirits and speaking with quiet courtesy. Dreams and visions are incubated there. It serves as a form of "red tent" for women's life cycle rituals.

Don't worry if you haven't done a sauna before! Unlike a sweat lodge, it is an experience that can be as intense or gentle as suits your body. Those who want the most heat sit on the highest of three shelves. The lowest level is safe even for babies. When you have had enough, you can jump into the pond to cool off . . . and then return to the sauna if you wish.
results.name: Women's Lodge Fall Equinox Circle

results.description:
NOTE:  3pm start time this month (to accommodate Steve) unless folks need us to start at 2pm 

18xx games are about railroads: building track and running trains for profit. 18xx games are also about a stock market, and the skullduggery between various robber barons as they try to build, thwart, take over, or bankrupt companies. But, they can take quite a while to play. We generally play with poker chips and try to emphasize a "ready to play" culture (we usually track operating order, so you know when your companies will act). Games have generally taken from 2 hours (via bankruptcy) to 6 hours (to the end) with the average around five hours, even with new players.


We try to be ready to start right at the starting time, or close to it, because the game is so long. New players are welcome although we suggest familiarizing yourself with the basic rules and concepts first. The game really isn't overly complex, rules-wise, it's just long with lots of decisions.

What you need to know about 334:

-Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building
-You must sign in at the security desk with a picture ID
-Take the elevator down to level "A." Exit the elevator to your left and the community room will be ahead on your right, next to the laundry room.

results.description:
This is the final presentation of MIT Hacking Arts. 

More info: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hacking-arts-2015-tickets-18169170478?access=ARTWEEK015

To participate, please register here: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/hacking-arts-2015-tickets-18169170478?access=ARTWEEK015


As the divisions between art, science, and technology become increasingly blurred, the interactions at the bleeding-edge of these disciplines produce more innovation and disruption than ever before. To extend these capabilities and inspire new advances in the creative industries, MIT Sloan’s Entertainment, Media & Sports Club presents Hacking Arts. Held at MIT’s Media Lab, Hacking Arts is a festival and hackathon bringing together musicians, artists, designers, entrepreneurs, and engineers to design and explore technology-based ventures in arts and entertainment.


The two day festival includes panel discussions featuring some of the top thought leaders in music, film, fashion, virtual reality, and the visual arts; as well as an exhibition of technologies that impact and showcase the creative process. These conversations infor

m and inspire industry practitioners and hackathon participants who take an idea and transform it into a tangible innovation in a creative industry over the course of the weekend.


Hacking Arts is opening up the hackathon presentations and judging to the public Sunday afternoon 3:00PM – 6:00PM


The hackathon begins at 4:30 Saturday, September 26 and runs until presentations and judging Sunday afternoon.

results.name: MIT Hacking Arts Sunday Presentation FREE

results.description:
Dr. Steve Blake, Director of the Center for Nutrition for Neurologic Diseases at Hawaii Pacific Neuroscience, will speak on 'Stroke: How to Reduce Your Risk' to BVS. FREE talk.  bostonveg.org , naturalhealthwizards.com 

Afterwards, you may opt to stay for Grasshopper's generous buffet for only $10.70 + tax + tip, including appetizers, soups, salad, and numerous entrees.

Learn how to reduce your risk of having a stroke. Strokes can be deadly or lead to long-term disability. Discover which single food can more than double your risk of stroke. See which food has been shown to lower stroke risk by 80%. Find out how to lower blood pressure to reduce stroke risk. Learn how to reduce arterial clogging and stroke risk with diet. Which spices, herbs, and supplements can help after a stroke?

This is in Union Square, Allston (part of Boston) the intersection of Cambridge St., Brighton Ave., and North Beacon St. Buses # 66, 57, and 64 stop there. Closest subway stop is Allston St. on the Green Line B trolley (Comm. Ave.) Or, you could take the T to Harvard Square or Coolidge Corner, where you can pick up the #66 bus that stops a block from Grasshopper. 

FREE street parking; allow time to find a spot.

Steve Blake is the faculty nutritional biochemist at Hawaii Pacific Neuroscience. He has designed the Hawaii Dementia Prevention Trial, a clinical study at the Hawaii Alzheimer’s Disease Center. He is author of the 2008 McGraw-Hill college textbook Vitamins and Minerals Demystified, Arthritis Relief, A Nutritional Approach to Alzheimer’s Disease, and Understanding Fats and Oils. He has written Mosby’s Alternative Remedies and is co-author of Mosby's Drug Guide for Nurses, 4th edition. He has a dozen videos on how food affects health. He also authored the Diet Doctor, software for analyzing dietary nutrients. Steve Blake attended the University of California. He is a clinical research scientist in nutritional biochemistry. He lives on an organic farm in Maui and offers classes at University of Hawaii.  

His dietary analysis software and books will be available for sale and signing after the talk. No credit cards.

https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcR-qJypABcZOvs13EbGTbiLaTvSDEJJ7D7NIYbyG2B1ilVzSfBXJg
results.name: Dr. Steve Blake 'Stroke: How to Reduce Risk'

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Give yourself the gift of relaxation and rejuvenation with a wonderful 90 minute gentle yoga and meditation class.

True relaxation is experienced by the body and mind when little or no energy is consumed. It is Nature's way of recharging. Since every action, conscious or unconscious, uses stored energy, relaxation is necessary for good health and peace of mind. Without proper relaxation the body and mind become overworked and inefficient.

When the mind is constantly bombarded by stimuli, it becomes overloaded and exhausted. We may be unaware that we are doing it, but by thinking and worrying we are using up tremendous amounts of energy. The tension put on the mind by worries can use more energy than physical work.

Yoga retrains the body to relax and can calm the mind which leads to inner peace.

This class is for beginners and experienced yogi's.  Chairs are available for those who may need to sit during this class.  Please bring your own yoga mat, water and a blanket or pillow for meditation.
results.name: Gentle Yoga & Meditation - 90 minute class

group.name: The Light Within - Yoga, Reiki, Meditation - Dorchester MA

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 37-52 SOLD OUT FOR WOMEN

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
Bless the Harvard Film Archive - they are running a Five O'Clock Shadow series on Sunday late afternoons -  Noir movies, some I've never seen.  On 9/27, they're showing "When Strangers Marry."  See the description below.  It's only 67 minutes long (a real plus in my book).  After we can go have dinner and discuss anxiety, conspiracies, and dread.  I'll figure out where we're going when I see how many people sign up and if the weather might be good enough for outdoor dining.

When Strangers Marry

Directed by William Castle. With Robert Mitchum, Kim Hunter, Dean Jagger
US 1944, 16mm, b/w, 67 min

Orson Welles was an avowed fan of William Castle’s B-noir classic, which packs careful suspense and shocking surprise into its taut sixty-seven minute story of a new bride united with the man she may, or may not, have married. When Strangers Marry offered an early role for a radiantly young Kim Hunter, whose wanderings through a haunted city of beckoning signs and darkened rooms suggest a kind of noir “Alice in Underworld.”
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be in the Center of the Theater before the movie.  After, I'll be outside the front doors.
results.name: When Strangers Marry

venue.name: Inner Space Meditation Center And Gallery

results.name: POSITIVE THINKING

results.description:
Join me for this regular monthly Full Moon Labyrinth Walk at the Somerville Growing Center (just outside of Union Square). I offer this outdoor labyrinth walk gathering each month on the Sunday nearest the full moon - May through October.

We'll have a little introduction of walking for those new to labyrinths and some fun discussion about the moon's current astrology and energy we might tap into for reflection or inspiration.

After our contemplative walk, those who wish, may linger for more conversation, community and snacks !

** Note the time change for this one - we start at 5:30 instead of 6:30!! (sadly our late day light is beginning to wane).

venue.address_1: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138
venue.name: Aberdeen Ave & Huron Ave, Cambridge, MA 02138

results.description:
Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :9/27@5:30

results.description:
Let's join five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]

results.description:
We are about to witness a rare celestial event on September 27th, when we will get an opportunity to see a "Total Lunar Eclipse" that will give a coppery red color to the moon thus earning it the designation of a "Blood Moon". Besides which, the moon will be closest to Earth earning it the distinction of, "Super Moon". Finally, because of the time of the month/year that this event occurs it has the unique distinction of being referred to as a "SUPER HARVEST BLOOD MOON". (How cool is that?)

To make things even more interesting for photographers, sunset will occur at 6:33 p.m. on the 27th and moon rise will occur at 6:24 p.m.  and will reach full moon status in 4 hour hours which coincides with the total eclipse. That means that conditions for photographing this event should be perfect. 

I will also provide you with the basics of creating a time lapse of the event.  You will need the right equipment and patience.

Key times of the evening:

• Partial Eclipse begins at 9:07 PM 

• Full Eclipse begins at 10:11 PM  

• Maximum Eclipse at 10:47 PM

• Full Eclipse ends at 11:23 PM

• Partial Eclipse ends at 12:27 AM

Equipment:

• A sturdy tripod is is a must and a remote shutter release is preferable.

• A normal to medium wide 50 mm and wider for a good panoramic scape

• A telephoto lens or a long zoom lens at around 200mm or greater if you want frame filling images.  Not the most suitable for time-lapse.

• Cameras capable of internal intervalometers and or an eternal intervalometer will be required for any time-lapse capture

• A small flashlight or headlamp (are filter is ideal)

• A small folding chair or camping stool - the total eclipse duration is over 3.5 hours

• A warm jacket, hat and if you are smart - a pair of gloves.  A thermos with a hot beverage is advisable.

We will meet at the Boston Harbor walk in the short term parking area of Boston Harbor Towers, 85 East India Row. This is adjacent to the New England Aquarium.  Please be there at 6:00 PM if you plan on photographing the Moonrise, 8:00 PM if you only want to capture images of the eclipse.

Your host will present a brief on location tutorial on how to best photograph this rare celestial event using East Boston as the anchoring element. We will have time to practice our techniques while catching the glowing sun's reflections on East Boston.
results.name: RARE -SUPER HARVEST BLOOD MOON and TOTAL LUNAR ECLIPSE - SEPTEMBER 27TH, 2015

results.description: We'll gather at 6:00pm in the parish kitchen at Grace Episcopal Church, 160 High Street in Medford. Please bring a prepared soup ingredient to add to the pot or a side dish, dessert, or drink. This week our discussion leader will be Mia!

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: Speeddating Ages 25-35--SOLD OUT FOR MEN

This outline motivates us to seek meaning in our lives at the same time providing emotional and spiritual support to each other. We hope that you will join us.  -Rich Emmel
results.how_to_find_us: We meet at the back of the building off of the driveway from Mystic Valley Parkway, go to the far back door.

group.name: Boston Open Men's Group - Personal Mastery Workgroup

results.description:
Come join us for a lively book discussion -  Euphoria by Lily King


A New York Times Bestseller, Winner of the 2014 Kirkus Prize,
Winner of the 2014 New England Book Award for Fiction,
A Finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award

A Best Book of the Year for:  New York Times Book Review, Time, NPR, Washington Post, Entertainment Weekly, Newsday, Vogue, New York Magazine, Seattle Times, San Francisco Chronicle, Wall Street Journal, Boston Globe, The Guardian, Kirkus Reviews, Amazon, Publishers Weekly, Our Man in Boston, Oprah.com, Salon...

Euphoria is Lily King’s nationally bestselling breakout novel of three young, gifted anthropologists of the ‘30’s caught in a passionate love triangle that threatens their bonds, their careers, and, ultimately, their lives. Inspired by events in the life of revolutionary anthropologist Margaret Mead.

"dazzling ... suspenseful ... brilliant...an exhilarating novel.”—Boston Globe

We will be choosing a book for December's meeting at this discussion; please come with a book suggestion. We encourage all ages, both men and women.


This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are at Panera. Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Please be considerate and change your RSVP if you cannot attend. All no shows from previous meetings or current meeting will be bumped to the end of the wait list!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for large table with meetup sign or the book.
results.name: Book Group - Euphoria by Lily King

results.description:
Cost is $59 per person
Discover the beauty of nature at night as you paddle through calm waters under the glow of the summer moon. We believe a full moon enhances the beauty of these secluded waters and creates a truly memorable adventure. On this leisurely excursion, you'll paddle comfortable, stable kayaks and get a chance to experience nature up close. After a short paddling demonstration, your experienced guide will lead you on a revealing tour, sharing interesting facts about the area's history and the surrounding landscape. As the moon rises higher in the sky, you'll start to see the fascinating wildlife that emerges when the sun sets.

There will be a Full Lunar Eclipse at 8:11 during this Kayak! 

This spectacular tour only occurs during the weeks of the full moon and is a special adventure you won't want to miss. No prior kayaking experience is needed. All necessary paddling equipment is provided.

What to Bring Print checklist (PDF)
•Weather-appropriate clothing (preferably synthetic*)
•Waterproof jacket and pants
•Personal prescriptions such as EpiPen or inhaler

Optional
•One-quart water bottle or hydration system
•Waterproof camera
•Water shoes or closed-toed shoes you don't mind getting wet
•10-foot or longer recreational kayak, paddle and US Coast Guard-approved Type III PFD†
•Extra change of clothes
•Towel

What We Provide
•Use of all necessary paddling equipment: boats, paddles, PFD's, etc.
•Closed-toed water shoes
•First-aid kit
•Water
•Insect repellant

In order for you to confirm your space please visit www.llbean.com/dedham, find the specific time and date of your event, and complete the registration (and payment process (as necessary).  We look forward to seeing you!
results.name: Full Moon Kayak Tour and Full Lunar Eclipse!

results.description:
We will have a full lunar eclipse visible from our location. The total eclipse is also known as "Blood Moon" because the moon suddenly turns dark red during when it is fully obstructed by the Earth.

Note: Limited attendance, strictly paid members only! Do not sign up for more than one event. If you drop out late, you will be marked as an no-show, please be considerate of others waiting. Very little parking available at the meeting point (4 cars), see "How to find us" for parking address.


Also note that organizers will assist you before the action begins, but then are there to shoot themselves. During the eclipse, there is limited assistance.


Somewhat clear skies are needed for this event, but the moon will be high in the sky for this (marine layer doesn't matter) and we will attempt to create photos like the one below that I did last year. The shot below was taken in 100% cloud cover (with occasional opening and intermittent rain). Also a great opportunity for time lapse photography. Very good chances for a spectacular event. The place we go to will have quite a bit of space.


Here is a link to a good overview.


Shooting the blood moon is very challenging, this is not for everyone! The brightness of the moon drops by seven (!) stops going from full moon to blood moon. You will need to adjust settings as the moon gets more obstructed and when it is fully obstructed, you need to quickly change from something like f/11, 1/200th second and ISO 100 to f/4, 1/100th second and ISO 800 or worse. If it is windy, you will have problems holding your lens steady and if you have only one camera, you will need to do both foreground and moon shots and change lenses accordingly. Very challenging shoot and I recommend that you participate only if you feel comfortable with all that (including being up all night on what will be a Monday morning).


6:25 pm: The moon comes up in the East, in case you want to capture it close to the horizon, but it will make for a long night.


7:30pm: It gets dark


8:11pm: Penumbral eclipse (slightly less brightness) begins


9:07pm: Partial Eclipse begins, 119°28.6' Partial moon eclipse starts - moon is starting to get red and is 27° above horizon
10:11pm: Total Eclipse begins, 133°37.7' Total moon eclipse starts - completely red (blood) moon. Moon is 38° above horizon.

10:47pm: Maximum Eclipse, 142°42.0' Moon is closest to the center of the shadow. Moon is 42° above horizon.


11:23pm: Total Eclipse ends, 153°45.4' Moon is 46° above horizon.

00:23am: Partial Eclipse ends , 175°48.7' Moon is 50° above horizon.


01:22am: Penumbral eclipse ends 


06:30: Moon sets in the West


The following graphic shows you the sequence with the five main points in time: partial eclipse begins, full eclipse begins, max eclipse (blood moon is during the full eclipse), full eclipse ends, partial eclipse ends. Outside of these five moons, you have a normal full moon (the penumbral shadow barely shows). The arc shows you the path of the moon from rise to set, a 12 hour span and you see the Milky Way at beginning and end of partial eclipse. This interesting eclipse portion is about 3 hours and 15 minutes long. The red blood moon will be visible for an hour and 10 minutes. 

Suggested equipment: the longest lens you got, maybe with teleconverter, plus wide angle lenses for foreground imagery. If you don't own a long lens, you can rent one for 4 days from LensRentals.com, BorrowLenses.com or locally from EP Levine in Waltham. I reserved a Nikon[masked]mm f/5.6 lens for $85 (incl shipping) for that weekend. There are cheaper solutions for 180/200mm lenses.


These are three locations at the place where we meet, all showing the moon in a southerly direction. Marina, pond and hillside locations.
results.name: Blood Moon 3!

results.description:
Enjoy a leisurely moonlight paddle on the lake with like-hearted others. This will be a special full moon with a total lunar eclipse, visible from our location, weather permitting!  Perhaps we'll visit the beaver lodges, maybe even see one going about its nocturnal busyness, or hear one slap its tail in warning. We'll quietly explore the lake, as we enjoy the evening air, the night sounds and the moonlight glimmering across the water. Then we'll return to shore, light the fire pit and enjoy toasted marshmallows and fine conversation.
We have canoes/kayak for eleven. You are also welcome to bring your own.
We look forward to celebrating each full moon throughout the summer this way.
$10 suggested donation.
results.how_to_find_us: Alllow extra time to find us the first time. Call to be guided in 978-579-0897. Look for beige two-story three-car garage on the left. Park anywhere except in front of garage doors. Walk around to the left side of the house to our door.

results.name: Total Lunar Eclipse

results.description:
Join us at the Arnold Arboretum this coming Sunday evening September 27, 2015 (weather permitting) to view the upcoming lunar eclipse and participate in a Druidic Full Moon Meditation for Peace ritual.

I have received reliable word from the Arboretum admin staff that although the grounds are technically closed at 5PM, the grounds have long been used as a public park by many residents and as long as no alcohol, open flames, or other shenanigans take place we will be allowed to gather on the grounds later in the evening without harassment.

The plan is to meet at the Forest Hills Gate at 8:30PM and then proceed in a silent walking meditation up the spiral route to the top of Bussey Hill, to spend time in silent meditation/reflection as the shadow spreads across the moon. Once we arrive at the top we will engage in a beautiful ritual that many modern Druids practice during the monthly full moon.

Following the ritual will be an eisteddfod, a traditional Celtic sharing of poetry and song. Feel free to bring any poems on the theme of peace, and if you are musically inclined feel free to bring your voice and/or an instrument to sing any inspirations.

The Forest Hills Gate is easily accessible by a short walk from the northern end of the Forest Hills station at the end of the MBTA’s orange line. Exit the north end of the station and turn right, go west along Arborway / Route 203 to the first opening into the park. There is limited parking in the area so public transportation is encouraged.

What to bring:
• layers of clothes in case it is a cool night
• something to sit on (blanket, yoga mat, etc)
• a small silver trinket (optional) to be purified by moonlight.
• Musical instruments if you are a player (for the Eisteddfod)
• Poems and/or songs, either found or personally written, about peace, love, and uplifting themes.


In Boston local time, the eclipse is set to begin at around 9:05PM, and the peak to occur at 10:45PM

The long-range forecast is for a clear sunny day, but things can change. If skies are overcast we will still meet to work with the moon “in essence” but if it is raining the event will be cancelled.

Maps of the Arboretum, including how to find the Forest Hills Gate, can be found here: http://arboretum.harvard.edu/wp-content/uploads/basic-map-b+w.pdf
results.name: Druidic Full Moon Meditation for Peace / Lunar Eclipse Observation

results.description:
The full moon that is closest to the autumnal equinox is known as the "Blood Moon". This year the blood moon is also a "supermoon" as it is closer to the earth than usual. Best of all is that we are also treated to a lunar eclipse! 

Here is the timetable for the eclipse:

Partial umbral eclipse begins: 9:07 p.m. EDT on September 27
Total eclipse begins: 10:11 p.m. EDT
Greatest eclipse: 10:47 p.m. EDT
Total eclipse ends: 11:23 p.m. EDT
Partial eclipse ends: 12:27 a.m. EDT on September 28


Moonrise is at 7:02 pm and I may plan on getting there early enough to capture that as well. Let me know if you are interested in showing up for this. 

There is lots of information on photographing lunar eclipses available online. I will post some links to some of the better articles over the next few weeks. The great thing about a lunar eclipse is that it happens slowly enough that you have time to experiment with different camera settings and exposures.

Equipment list:

• Camera with zoom lens and capable of shooting in manual mode


• Tripod


• Remote shutter release (or set shutter on 2 sec delay)


• Flashlight (Please use a red flashlight if needed for making camera adjustments. White lights are too likely to get into other's shots.)


• You may want a second camera on a tripod with a wider angle lens if you wish to take stacked images of the progression of the eclipse over time. I will try to find more information on this technique as well. 


• Warm clothing. Snacks, drinks. A camping chair might be nice to have as well.


As always we recommend people carpool. 

Castle Island, South Boston as viewed from Boston Harbor
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in front of Sullivan's restaurant. (Some of us will be arriving earlier, so look around the area for tripods and a telescope if you arrive early!)

It's week 4 of the 2015 Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing. FREE: The comedy club experience is called the Liquid Courage Comedy Club at Somerville Brewing Company. The brewery and destination-taproom, which opened in April of 2105, opens Sunday nights as a showcase style stand-up comedy club open to the public 21+ with no cover charge or ticket fee. Guests are able to order charcuterie boards, dinner and pints during, before and after the show. With a Sunday night show time of 9PM there is ample free parking available.

Season 1, the 2015 dates are as follows: September 13th, 20th and 27th, October 4th, 11th and 25th, November 1st 8th 15th and 22nd December 6th 13th 20th and 27th.

The opening night on September 6th filled to capacity and guests were entertained by 7 professional comedians and show host C.J. Browne. “We’re excited to offer a curated show of experienced local comedians. Since the room and setup require excellence the showcase is not an open mic night. We are absolutely psyched about the success of opening night. We played to a full house that loved the show.” Show performer Gary Peterson says “The Slumbrew comedy show was such a fun room to work, because the owners care about making it fun. A packed house of young heroes supporting the local scene makes this place special. It makes me happy to know something so cool is alive in Somerville.”
