results.name: Lunar Eclipse

results.description:
How much life passes you by? A full moon, supermoon, blood moon combo has only happened five times since 1900. The last time was in 1982.  We'll watch this from the highest point we can.  If you decide to miss out on this one, your next chance won't be until 2033. 


Sunday night we have a truly amazing triple celestial event – a full moon, a super-moon, and a lunar eclipse will coincide for an hour.

The full moon will rise at 6:24. This particular full moon is special all by itself because it is a "super-moon" -- at its closest point to the earth.  A super moon appears 14% larger and 30% brighter because of its closeness. 

But this rare super-moon is even more rare, because at 8:11, it will start to pass through the shadow of our earth. As the lunar eclipse progresses, it turns blood red as our earth blocks most of the sun's light, but the red light still makes it past us, and is reflected back to us, turning the moon an apparent red.

That gives us the extremely rare, full, super, blood moon.  Last seen in 1982, and not to be seen again until 2033.

Timing

9:15PM: Meet at the second parking lot north on Route 138.  If you are coming from Route 128, we will be just past the Trailside Museum. (Pass the ski slope, the first parking lot on your right, and the Trailside museum, and then enter the (second) parking lot (on the right).)  
- - > Map to the Second Parking Lot

9:20PM: We will do an equipment check (see list below.)  For your safety and comfort, please be sure to have all equipment. (For safety reasons, anyone without the mandatory equipment cannot be part of our group.)

9:25PM: Drop Deadline (For safety reasons, anyone arriving after 9:25 may not be part of our group.)

9:30PM: Hike up the paved road to the top of Blue Hill, the highest point in Norfolk County.  

10:00PM: Visit both the observatory and the tower, and decide which affords the best viewing and most comfort. 

10:11PM: Total eclipse starts.

10:20PM: Share our thoughts on this metaphor for our lives while we enjoy the night, the view of Boston, of the harbor, of the country side, and of the encompassing blood eclipse of the full super-moon.

10:47: Peak of the eclipse

11:00: Return by the road to our cars.

11:20: Hug and leave as the total eclipse ends.

Mandatory Equipment: 


- flashlight (with red filter best)
- warm hat
- long pants
- gloves/mittens
- shirt layers to add or peel off
- wind breaker or coat
- sturdy shoes and warm socks
- yummy snack to share 
- water bottle
- back pack or sack to carry it all
- love and comradeship

Metaphoric questions:
- When have you been "eclipsed"? Has any of these eclipses produced a greater beauty in your life?
- When have you experienced multiple themes in your life coming together at the same time, that produced a incredible result?
- When is your next momentous life event?

Your Guide:
Dennis has hiked Blue Hills for 25+ years.  He is the organizer of the Personal Growth Network, loves the outdoors, and is entranced by cosmic events

Liability Waiver:


As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following:

- This activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others. 

- You assume all risk associated with this activity; 

- You are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity

- You know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at www.hikesafe.com.

- The leader(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify the leader(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet at the second parking lot, just north of the ski slope parking lot and the Trailside Museum.  Travel north (towards Boston) on Route 138 from Rt 128.  The second parking lot after the museum is right before Canton Avenue splits.
results.name: Dennis: A Full, Super, Blood Moon, from atop Blue Hill

venue.name: Phillips Auditorium, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics

results.description:
Events for the Public

The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics sponsors a variety of free programs for the public. Among these events are Observatory Nights held on the third Thursday of the month (excluding June, July and August). Observatory Nights feature a nontechnical lecture and telescopic observing from the observatory roof if weather permits. The lectures are intended for high-school age and older audiences but children are also welcome. We also sponsor a variety of other special observing events throughout the year. No reservations are necessary, but seating is limited to the auditorium's capacity. Admission is free.

These events--unless otherwise noted--are held in Phillips Auditorium (at the rear of the CfA complex near Madison Street and large parking lot), 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, about 1 mile west of Harvard Square. Parking lots marked for Observatory Staff are open to the public on event nights. Parking is free.

The Observatory does not host private events.

Monthly Observatory Night
Sunday, September 27, 2015
7:30 pm:  Lunar Eclipse Viewing

For more information, including accessibility, or to sign up for the events mailing list, call the Public Affairs Office, (617)[masked] or email [masked]. Please request sign-language interpretation at least 2 weeks before the event. Current sky information is available.

Entrance is at the west of the CfA complex, near Madison Street and large parking lot. The CfA is easily reached by public transportation. From the Harvard MBTA Station (Red Line), take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses, Huron Avenue trolleys) and get off at "Observatory Hill."

Source(s): http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/publicevents

Also available via their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ObsNights

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Monday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

results.description:
Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Please, we aware door closes at 6:00, so come 5 minutes early to enter freely. If not, please comment in the meetup page and will come for you.

The meeting will start 6pm sharply to avoid be late. This time we have Lina presenting, thanks!

Lina will discuss how to perform a basic "16S metagenomics" experiment that can tell you about microbial abundances in a clinical or environmental sample. She will expand on her experiences with two of the most commonly used tools in the field, qiime and mothur. If time permits, she will also touch briefly on how to perform functional metagenomics studies, i.e. determining not just who is there but also what the bacteria in the community are doing.
results.name: 16S metagenomics

results.description:
For our kick-off meeting, we'll have an introduction to Open edX, and a presentation from Aquent about their use of Open edX.

What is Open edX: edX's Ned Batchelder will present an overview of Open edX, the open-source platform that powers edx.org and hundreds of other online education sites around the world.  What is it, how can you use it, and where is it going?


Aquent: Aquent's Gymnasium was built and launched on a proprietary MOOC platform in 2013. Two years later, they are relaunching their design school - built on top of Open edX. 

Andrew Miller and Jeremy Osborn will be sharing some tales from this adventure - including the business, technical, and pedagogical decisions, as well as the death-defying stunts required to (re)shape the user experience appropriately. 

About the speakers

Ned Batchelder is a software architect at edX.  He's also an organizer of Boston Python, and likes to juggle.


Andrew Miller is a designer, a hacker, and the Program Director at the Aquent Gymnasium.

Jeremy Osborn is an accomplished author and the academic director of Aquent Gymnasium. He has built websites for Boston-area startups, developed a Graphic & Interactive Design certificate program at Boston University, and consulted for a number of companies, including Google, Microsoft, and Adobe. His latest book, HTML5 Digital Classroom, is an excellent resource for learning the essentials of HTML5 and is available on Amazon.


We'll also have an open discussion time to hear from all of you: what is your interest in Open edX, what would you like this group to be like, and what would you like to hear about in the future?


Pizza will be provided by edX.
results.name: First meeting!

venue.name: Microsoft New England Research and Development Center

results.description:
Agenda

• 6:30: Food and Networking

• 7:00: Presentations

Presentation 1: Creating Sustainability in WP Client Handoff

Is there anything more heartbreaking than visiting a site 6 months after handoff to find it in disarray? Or coming to the end of a project so frustrated that the idea of client training is painful? We’ll go through 15 best practices you can undertake to ensure the website you turn over is sustainable, that client and provider leave the experience happier and we all stop wasting eachother’s time. Practices will cover internal processes as well as inherent WP tools to create better workflow and UI on the dashboard.

Amanda Blum

A marketing and web services provider for more than 15 years, A longstanding and respected member of the WordPress community, Amanda has organized two of the largest and most popular WordCamp Conferences as well speaking at WordPress meetups in Boston, San Francisco, Providence, Phoenix and New York and WordCamps all over the world on e-commerce, NPO integration with WordPress and content strategy/information architecture using WordPress.

Presentation 2: Recovering from a WordPress Hack

Has you site ever been Hacked? Several of our have. In this presentation Greg will cover what to do after a site has been hacked including: What to look for in files and/or return emails.  What can be deleted and replaced to what to look for in files that just need to be looked.  I will be taking a look at some linux commands on how to search files for known inserts.

Greg Whitehead

Greg Whitehead is a Sr. Web Developer for inConcert Web Solutions where he has been developing for 8 years.  From building custom e-commerce solutions and web apps to customizing existing clients websites he has almost 20 years working on the web.  His love for programming started back in the 80's while programming in QBasic and playing QBasic Gorillas on one of his first computers. He picked up a PHP/MySql book in 2005 to learn how to build a login script and hasn't stopped developing web applications since. His focus has been on WordPress and WordPress development for the past 6 years. Currently he has 7 plugins in the WordPress repository and so far all the reviews he has received have been 5 stars. Managing multiple dedicated servers has given him a lot of experience with hosting configurations from managing DNS to recovering from a hacked website.  He also has many personal websites two of which are wp-411 and wpcmx ninja
results.name: Creating Sustainability in WP Client Handoff & Recovering from a WordPress Hack

results.description:
New:

Due to time constraints and the game being very adjustable to new players joining and leaving at any time, I am making a change.

I do wish people to get something to compensate IHOP for letting us use the space, however, if you have not started or finished eating by 7:15pm please, start or finish eating at another table. The rest of the people will clean the table and start playing.  I want the rest of the players to have a chance to finish a game.


The rules give new players the opportunity to join the game at the start of any new hand, with the score of the mean player.

I am trying to keep the game and conversation balanced for everyone.  If multiple players are eating, conversing and playing,  the game may be held up until some people are restless.

Also, the more people eating and playing while handling the cards, the greater chance the few decks of "Jumbo Index" cards used for Negation Hearts will be marked and hard to shuffle, detracting from the game.

As always, please put your cold drinks on a napkin.

Thank you;

Negation Hearts Night. New players are VERY welcome: We will teach you how to play.

It is suggested that you get a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment. .

PUBLIC:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have nearby stops. 

Negation Hearts is played with two decks of cards. Two of the same cards like two king of clubs negate and the next highest card of the suit lead takes the cards played. So, even playing a two has not been safe at times. The scoring and passing are slightly altered from "Cancellation" hearts so that new people can join in or leave at the start of any hand.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced between the two.
results.name: Negation Hearts in Salem @ IHOP *

results.description:
Heart disease is the #1 cause of death in the United States. It doesn't need to be: Dr. Steve Blake, nutritional biochemist, says we can virtually eliminate it as a cause of death.

Research shows that diet is strongly linked to heart attacks. There are plenty of tasty, healthy foods that you can add to your diet to reduce your risk of a heart attack. Dr. Blake will discuss the spectrum of food choices, how clogged arteries develop, and how to stop and even reverse this clogging. Come and learn the truth about saturated fats and trans fats (“Did you know there are trans fats in milk and beef?”). Learn the health aspects and sources of omega-3 fatty acids, how to reduce heart attack risk by reducing inflammation, and about “cholesterol crystals.”

Dr. Blake will review the latest research so that you can choose heart-safe lifestyle options.

Steve has a friendly and warm, conversational style of speaking. Some of you may remember Dr. Blake from his last visit to Boston, almost exactly one year ago, when he and his wife visited, spoke, and sold some of their books, cookbooks, and computer software:

http://www.meetup.com/HOLISTIC-HEALTH-SPEAKER-SERIES-AND-STUDY-GROUP/events/206076632/

They’re back! Hope you can join us.


>>>>

Steve Blake, ScD is a research specialist in nutritional biochemistry and the faculty nutritional biochemist at Hawaii Pacific Neuroscience. He teaches at the University of Hawaii and has taught at Stanford University, McLean Hospital, and at Boston University Medical Center.

Dr. Blake is the author of the 2008 McGraw-Hill college textbook Vitamins and Minerals Demystified, as well as How NOT to get a Heart Attack, Arthritis Relief, A Nutritional Approach to Alzheimer’s Disease, and Understanding Fats and Oils. He has written Mosby’s Alternative Remedies and is the co-author of Mosby's Drug Guide for Nurses, 4th edition. He also authored the Diet Doctor, which is software for analyzing dietary nutrients.

He is the creator of The Herb Doctors database with worldwide medical plant information.

Steve earned a doctor of science degree in holistic health, specializing in nutritional biochemistry. He and his wife Catherine live on a solar-powered organic farm on Maui.
results.name: HOW TO HAVE A HEALTHY HEART (and totally prevent heart attacks)

I will moderate the discussion and give you my two cents in response to your questions but I also hope to get others to chime in with their thoughts and viewpoints.


Questions will be encouraged but not required.  You are also welcome to just come and listen in on the discussion. 


As another way off possibly spurring some conversation, I would also like to try doing a few image critiques. If you are interested in a gentle but honest critique of a few of your images in a group setting, please send an email to [masked] and I will send detailed instructions. This is being done on a trial basis to see what people think and I don’t want to take up too much time with it so it will be limited to the first 5 people to reply to me with interest.


Hope to see you on September 28th!


Note :  We have the room reserved from 6 PM - 9 PM but I am allowing half an hour at the beginning for set up time.  You are welcome to arrive at 6 PM to "meet and greet" but the group discussion will begin at 6:30 PM.  The discussion portion will conclude at 8:30 PM to allow time for packing up and getting the room cleared out as we must vacate the library by 9 PM sharp.


Note : The library is also currently featuring an exhibit of photographs by members of the Bedford Center for the Arts Photo Group. Come early and check it out!

Note : All Bedford Library events are free and open to the public.  You do not need to join the Meetup to attend but doing so is the best way of being notified about future events.

results.description:
September's book is All Souls: A Family Story from Southie, by Michael Patrick MacDonald.

From Amazon.com: A breakaway bestseller since its first printing, All Souls takes us deep into Michael Patrick MacDonald's Southie, the proudly insular neighborhood with the highest concentration of white poverty in America. Rocked by Whitey Bulger's crime schemes and busing riots, MacDonald's Southie is populated by sharply hewn characters like his Ma, a miniskirted, accordion-playing single mother who endures the deaths of four of her eleven children. Nearly suffocated by his grief and his community's code of silence, MacDonald tells his family story here with gritty but moving honesty.
results.name: North Shore Book Group

results.description:
Launch It is a monthly presentation series where product experts share their lessons and epiphanies with you. You’ll come away with proven strategies for product success.

Launch It is perfect for UX professionals, product managers, engineers, and marketing practitioners who want to take their products to the next level. Learn more about the upcoming Launch It events on the Perfetti Media web site.

Program and Agenda

6:30 - 7:15: Wine, beer, and hors d'oeuvres: Grab a drink and meet the best and brightest people in the world of product management, design, and development

7:15 - 8:00 - Interview with Jeremy Crane, VP of Product HubSpot: HubSpot's Transformation to Small, Cross-functional Product Teams

8:00 - 8:30 - Networking 

Your $10 Registration Includes:

• An interactive interview with Jeremy Crane, HubSpot's VP of Product

• Complimentary drinks, including beer, wine, and soda

• Tasty hors d’oeuvres

• Networking with brilliant minds from the Boston product community

Program Highlights: An Evening with Jeremy Crane, VP Product, HubSpot

At this month's event, we'll conduct an in-depth interview with Jeremy Crane, VP of Product at HubSpot, about his lessons learned as HubSpot made the transition to small,-cross-functional product teams.

Jeremy will discuss how dedicated and autonomous teams successfully drove improvements across HubSpot's product offerings.

results.description:
Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

•  Anyone from the community can participate. 


• Led by experienced runners. 


• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 


• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 


• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

• Our Fall session will begin on Monday, September 28.

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

Our Couch to 5K will end with the "Dedham Turkey Trot" on Thanksgiving morning.

results.description:
This months selected book is The Girl on the Train by Paula Hawkins:

http://www.amazon.com/The-Girl-Train-Paula-Hawkins/dp/1594633665

A debut psychological thriller that will forever change the way you look at other people's lives.

Rachel takes the same commuter train every morning. Every day she rattles down the track, flashes past a stretch of cozy suburban homes, and stops at the signal that allows her to daily watch the same couple breakfasting on their deck. She’s even started to feel like she knows them. “Jess and Jason,” she calls them. Their life—as she sees it—is perfect. Not unlike the life she recently lost.

And then she sees something shocking. It’s only a minute until the train moves on, but it’s enough. Now everything’s changed. Unable to keep it to herself, Rachel offers what she knows to the police, and becomes inextricably entwined in what happens next, as well as in the lives of everyone involved. Has she done more harm than good?

I will supply light snacks and drinks, but please feel free to bring your favorite snacks and beverages to share.

I'll message attendees with my address a few days prior to the meetup.

Looking forward to catching up with everyone and meeting new neighbors!

Due to seating limitations, I unfortunately have to limit the group to 10 people.  If your plans change, it would be greatly appreciated if you update your RSVP in case anyone waitlists. Thanks!
results.name: September Book Club Night - The Girl on the Train

An evening workshop designed to inspire each of us to the greatness we hold within.


- Re-connect to your heart's truest purpose and re-commit to bringing it to life 


- Explore courage as a quality that comes from within your own heart

- Identify and move beyond the blocks to living your your highest purpose so that each day is filled with meaning 

- Recognize how your heart can guide you to greater abundance 

Facilitator: Mike Connor

Michael Connor has been designing and presenting personal and professional development keynotes and trainings worldwide since 1993. A highly talented trainer and facilitator, he has presented programs on four continents, including Eastern & Western Europe, Russia, Israel, and Brazil, among others. Mike Connor leads corporate strategy seminars for Fortune 500 companies.  A business professional with a wealth of practical expertise, he is the former President and CEO of the Insight Educational Institute and a former health care executive. 

His strong personal growth background includes leading Insight Boston, facilitating Insight seminars, creating and facilitating his own workshops, leading men's work, and numerous interactions with parent-child workshops. He has written a book, Insights of a Father, reflecting on personal growth through fatherhood. 

Mike holds Masters Degrees in Health Care Management and Practical Theology.  While consulting to the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria and simultaneously starting Insight Bulgaria, he met his wife, Maria, a physician.  He is a dedicated father to two beautiful teenagers and lives with his family locally.

results.description:
Next time we're reading From Hell, by Alan Moore!

Note Well: We're meeting on a Monday this time; I have a conflict Tuesday (and Wednesday), and the following week is the Sci-Fi club's Monthly Social.


The Bumf:

 Legendary comics writer Alan Moore and artist Eddie Campbell have created a gripping, hallucinatory piece of crime fiction about Jack the Ripper. Detailing the events that led up to the Whitechapel murders and the cover-up that followed, From Hell has become a modern masterpiece of crime noir and historical fiction.

If you plan on coming, once you've read the book please post one discussion question in the comments for this event. I'll bring a list of them with me, and as usual we'll have them there to draw from when we're looking for stuff to talk about. I won't turn you away if you don't, but let's make running these things a group effort!

For those who haven't been to the Comic Book Club before, it's pretty simple - we sit around, order some food and some drink, and we probe deep into the merits and meanings of our chosen book or books. I also bring along a list of questions (written by you!) to give the discussion a bit of structure - but don't worry - it's pretty casual!

The venue is the Friendly Toast, which is a very casual kinda place with plenty of room where we can easily be heard. Please note though, that it's best to bring cash - although supposedly their card minimum has been relaxed - perhaps even obliterated!
results.how_to_find_us: We gather on the couches in the front beforehand, and once we have a quorum we get a table -- usually one of the booths or the tables in the very back if it's a large group. Ask the staff if you can't find us!
results.name: From Hell by Alan Moore

results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q. What About X-Wing?
A. If you noticed, this spot is filling up the time previously scheduled for X-Wing Miniatures 100pts - so... as you may have guessed, Randy and I will be setting up a couple of x-wing miniatures tables for those of us inclined towards that game but still want to make the event more inclusive to other game genres (it is not often the wife allows me to invite my friends to play games, so I better make the best use of the time).

results.description:
Science and Cooking returns! - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public. 

:: :: ::

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA - Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

:: :: ::

These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Mass., Hall C) and begin at 7 p.m. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s classSeating for all lectures is first come, first seated. If you have questions regarding this public lecture series, please contact [masked]. 

Sample Lecture: Explorations of Chocolate Textures [Lecture 4 (2012)]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt9g2se1LcM&index=10&list=PL546CD09EA2399DAB


 Full schedule

Lecture 1) Monday, Sept. 7 - Thinking about Flavor - Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” and Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”


Lecture 2) Monday, Sept. 14 - Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto

Lecture 3) Monday, Sept. 21 - The Science of Sugar - Joanne Chang ’91, (@jbchang), Flour Bakery, author of “Flour” and “Flour Too”

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA* - *Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

Lecture 8) Monday, Nov. 2 - Title TBA - Bryan Voltaggio, (@BryanVoltaggio), Volt*Michael Voltaggio, (@MVoltaggio), Ink

Lecture 9) Monday, Nov. 16 - Fermentation on Wheels: Food Education and Community Impact - Tara Whitsitt, (@tarawhitsitt), Fermentation on Wheels

Lecture 10) Monday, Nov. 23 - Title TBA - Nathan Myhrvold, (@ModernCuisine), former Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft, co-founder of Intellectual Ventures, author of “Modernist Cuisine”

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

The Harvard College Course: The Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) Limited to currently enrolled Harvard undergraduates, the class brings together eminent Harvard researchers and world-class chefs. 

:: :: ::

A version of “Science and Cooking” is offered for credit through the Harvard Extension School. An online course will be offered in the fall and spring semesters. Registered students will have access to the expertise and support of Harvard teaching staff.

:: :: ::

For more info visit <a>www.seas.harvard.edu.</a>

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from cubbies if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
IN ORDER TO VIEW THIS EVENT, YOU MUST RSVP. WE WILL SEND YOU A LINK TO THE EVENT ON THE DAY OF THE EVENT.

Please join us on September 28, 2015 for the next Access Silicon Valley event, "VC/Founder Showcase," where seed investors and their star portfolio companies discuss topics relevant to entrepreneurs and investors.

THE EVENT FEATURES:

• Rebecca Kaden, a partner at MAVERON CAPITAL (investors in Zulily, ebay, Groupon, Shutterfly, General Assembly),

• Duncan Davidson, a serial entrepreneur and Managing Partner of BULLPEN CAPITAL (investors in Marketo, Tanium, Zynga, FanDuel, ipsy), and

• Aarthi Ramamurthy, a serial entrepreneur and CEO of LUMOID, a hot YCombinator startup that is disrupting traditional retail by letting you rent equipment and gear of all sorts and kinds, and if you like what you rent, you can purchase it!

.

In this interactive, audience led discussion, Rebecca, Aarthi and Duncan will discuss:

• why Lumoid is disruptive and how Aarthi figured this out;

• how founders should view their ideas, and how disruptive they may be;

• how VCs react to such deals, and how to position to them;

• the most efficient and effective ways to raise capital in today’s environment, from an investors' and founder's perspective;

• what investors are looking for, how to reach them, andwhat entrepreneurs need to do (and not do) to get a meeting and raise a successful round.

Entrepreneurs will gain a practical perspective and insight into the the way in which they fundamentally think about their ideas and how to position them to investors.

AGENDA:

10:00PM - 11:30/12:00AM (EST): Chat with Rebecca, Aarthi and Duncan + Q&A

ABOUT THE SPEAKERS:


Rebecca Kaden joined Maveron when she was earning her MBA at Stanford, and is now a partner.  In 2015, Forbes named Rebecca to its annual list of top “30 under 30” in venture capital, and Craig Newmark named Rebecca one of “5 Women Investors You Need to Know.”

In her role at Maveron, Rebecca identifies emerging consumer-focused entrepreneurs. She also plays a leading role in Maveron's seed program, where Maveron partners with emerging consumer companies at their earliest stages. She’s a Board Observer at August, Darby Smart, Dolls Kill, Eargo, Earnest and General Assembly.

In a prior life, Rebecca was a journalist—for the Economist in London and as special projects editor at Narrative, an online literary platform devoted to bringing great literature into the digital age. At Narrative, in her addition to her editorial responsibilities, she was in charge of driving revenue and scaling the user base. Now she brings her skills and passion for understanding how stories come together to looking at the potential of breakout consumer brands. Rebecca earned her undergraduate degree from Harvard.

Maveron is a consumer-only venture capital firm. Founded in 1998 by Dan Levitan and Howard Schultz (Starbucks), the firm has offices in Seattle and San Francisco. -Some of Maveron's current and former portfolio companies include:

Aarthi Ramamurthy was a product manager at Netflix, worked on the Visual Studio, CLR and Xbox LIVE teams at Microsoft, was an EIR at Battery Ventures and co-created bubblegum - voted one of the top Windows Phone apps of 2011, before starting Lumoid.

Buying gadgets used to be a thrill, but now it’s a drag. There are so many to consider, that the choices become overwhelming, and then it seems they’re obsolete five minutes after you buy them.

Lumoid thinks there’s a better way, which may disrupt the way we think about owning electronics: Stop buying your gadgets, and rent them! Lumoid undermines the very idea of owning, and hopes to do for electronics what Uber and Zipcar have done for cars, Spotify and Pandora have done for music and Airbnb has done for vacation homes: replace ownership with access.

Lumoid’s model allows you to rent equipment and gear of all sorts and kinds, from camera lenses to wearables, to apple watches, drones, gaming systems and 3D printers. If you like what you rent, you can purchase it with a portion of the rental cost credited toward the purchase price.

Duncan Davidson is a serial entrepreneur who most notably founded Covad Communications (the leading independent DSL provider, went public and reached a market value of $9B) and Sky Pilot Networks (developer of outdoor wireless mesh systems, acquired by Trillium in 2009 for connectivity to smart meters).

He served as the SVP of Business Development at InterTrust and led the IPO in 1999 and the secondary in 2000 (InterTrust reached a $9B market value in 2000). He spent four years as a managing director at VantagePoint Venture Partners where he focused on digital media and telecom investments including Widevine (acquired by Google) and Livescribe.

Prior to Bullpen, he co-founded one of the first mobile social app companies, Xumii, later sold to Myriad Group and now powering over 20M users in the developing world. At Bullpen he focuses on mobile and consumer Internet investments, and sits on the boards of DoubleDutch, SendHub, and Proformative. Key investments include Byliner, PaidPiper and Twenty20. He received a Sc.B. in physics/math from Brown University, with Honors, and a J.D. magna cum laude from Michigan Law School, where he was Order of the Coif and a member of the Law Review.

Bullpen is the leader in post-seed, pre Series A funding of companies that have achieved market fit and that have an operational plan to hit big milestones within 12 months.Some of Bullpen's current and former portfolio companies include:

EVENT SPONSORS:



Founders Den is a shared office space and private club for experienced entrepreneurs and their friends

Procopio - Ranked among the 2015 Best Law Firms by U.S. News & World Report

West Agile Labs - A premier web & mobile, design & development agency that is passionate about building products that work and scale.
results.name: FREE: VC/FOUNDER SHOWCASE: VC@Maveron, VC@Bullpen & CEO of Lumoid (a YC Company)

Join Eric Siegel, founder of Predictive Analytics World, for an eye-opening executive breakfast — witness an accessible, concrete overview of how predictive analytics drives actionable value. Submit Request to Attend This Event:
http://www.predictiveanalyticsworld.com/patimes/executive-breakfast/

You must register & be on the list. Registration is free and you receive a complimentary copy of Eric Siegel’s acclaimed book Predictive Analytics: The Power to Predict Who Will Click, Buy, Lie, or Die. Free access to our exhibit floor and Breakfast along with hearing Eric's Keynote.

Date: Tuesday, September 29, 2015
Location: Seaport World Trade Center, Boston

Be among the first to participate in this inaugural event and spend a morning gathering valuable insight to enhance your predictive analytics efforts. Attendance is FREE, but by invitation only – click here to request an invitation. Space is limited, so submit your request today.

Who Should Attend:
Executives and senior leaders responsible for making value from data

Why Attend:
To discover how predictive analytics works, and the ways in which it delivers value to organizations across industry sectors. To build relationships with peers, leverage their insights, follow their progress and share your saga.

Breakfast and Keynote Presentation:
Predictive Analytics: Five Ways It Generates Value
Speaker: Eric Siegel , founder, Predictive Analytics World

The excitement over “big data” has grown dramatically. But what is the value, the function, the purpose? The most actionable win to be gained from data is prediction. This is achieved by analytically learning from data how to render predictions for each individual. Such predictions drive more effectively the millions of operational decisions that organizations make every day. In this keynote, Predictive Analytics World founder and Predictive Analytics author Eric Siegel reveals how predictive analytics works, and covers five ways in which it delivers value to organizations across industry sectors.

Submit Request to Attend This Event (Must be Approved):
http://www.predictiveanalyticsworld.com/patimes/executive-breakfast/

Interested in attending PAW(Predictive Analytics Wolrd)? Check out the agenda here & private message me for a great discount code!

http://www.predictiveanalyticsworld.com/boston/2015/agenda_overview.php
results.name: Predictive Analytics: Five Ways It Generates Value

Please join us for IBM Container Services and Docker Workshop!  Networking and dinner at 5:30 PM, with presentation and labs starting at 6:30 PM.


Presented by:  Raghavan "Rags" Srinivas (@ragss), Architect/Developer Evangelist

IBM Bluemix, an Enterprise-grade cloud platform has very recently offered a hosted Docker service. This allows developers to leverage the transportability of containers and the myriad of services offered in Bluemix on a platform that is highly available and scalable.


We will learn the concepts with a few fast-paced simple exercises based around IBM containers. Please follow steps 1-4 to install the prerequisite software (Docker, CF CLI and ic plugin) - https://www.ng.bluemix.net/docs/containers/container_cli_ov.html#container_cli_ov

Although a preliminary understanding of the Cloud Foundry commands (cf CLI) and Docker would be useful, it’s not absolutely necessary. After attending this Hands-On session, attendees will be able to walk away with an understanding of the power of IBM Containers that builds atop Docker and Cloud Foundry.


Still haven't registered for your free Bluemix account? Sign up here to get started: www.ibm.biz/cloudboston

BGN Fans, 


We're excited to bring you September's Board Game Night, as always hosted by East Coast Product, and this month sponsored by Beam, WeWork Fort Point, Downeast Cider House and Bully Boy Distillers. 

Your $5 registration includes drinks and snacks. All proceeds benefit the ever awesome Resilient Coders, an organization dedicated to making web tech education more accessible to urban youth. WeWork has offered to match every donation so your $5 donation is going a lot further.

Half-networking, half-gaming -- it's the only event in Boston that brings together innovation enthusiasts for an evening of friendly competition and great conversation. Don't forget to spread the word use the hashtag #BGNio and tweet us @BGNio to stay in the loop and build our community.

Our games include:

• Settlers of Catan

• Race to the Galaxy

• Dominion

• Marvel Legendary

• Succession

• Puerto Rico

• DiXit

• San Juan

• Or bring your own! 

SPONSORS

East Coast Product is the fastest most efficient way to build the right digital product to get your startup to it's next milestone.

Beam is a simple, private, free app that lets two people share their current locations in real-time for one hour.


The only person who sees you is the person you’ve Beamed. And, you must both agree to Beam before you can see each other. With Beam there are no surprises. It's simple to use and the Beam Bar makes it very clear who can see you and for how long. You can stop a Beam at any time and your Beaming history is never saved.


WeWork is the community for creators. We transform buildings into beautiful, collaborative workspaces and provide infrastructure, services, events and technology so our members can focus on doing what they love. We currently have 20 locations in eight cities with over 11,000 members. Book a tour at wework.com

Dave and Will Willis founded Bully Boy Distillers, Boston’s first craft distillery, in 2010. The two were inspired by Charlescote Farm, their family’s fourth-generation farm in Sherborn, Mass. During Prohibition, the Willis brothers’ grandfather housed an enviable collection of artisanal spirits in the farmhouse’s basement vault, which also served as an underground speakeasy. Having been raised on Charlescote, Dave and Will are proud to honor their family’s tradition of local agriculture, helping to run the farm in addition to managing the distillery.


BACK BY POPULAR DEMAND: New England's Craft Cider. Locally grown. Freshly Pressed. Gluten-Free. Not from Concentrate.

results.description:
5:30 - 6:00 PM - Pizza and Networking


How to Work with Content Experts to Optimize and Maintain Search Relevancy

Getting good search results is hard; maintaining good relevancy is even harder. Fixing one problem can easily create many others. Without good tools to measure the impact of relevancy changes, there’s no way to know if the “fix” that you’ve developed will cause relevancy problems with other queries. Ideally, much like we have unit tests for code to detect when bugs are introduced, we would like to create ways to measure changes in relevancy.

This is exactly what was done at OSC. They have developed a series of tools and practices that allow them to work with content experts to define metrics for search quality. Once defined, they can instantly measure the impact of modifying their relevancy strategy, allowing them to iterate quickly on very difficult relevancy problems.

Doug Turnbull

Is a Solr and Elasticsearch consultant for OpenSource Connections and the author of the book "Relevant Search". Doug lives and breathes smart, relevant search and focuses on moving his clients away from basic text matching to search with domain and business intelligence built in. He leverages search engine features such as Lucene internals and user signals to craft more relevant search results. Doug bridges the gap between content experts, search analytics, and technologists. To help bridge the gap, Doug created Quepid, a search relevancy collaboration canvas used extensively in OpenSource Connection's search work, and Splainer a Solr search results explanation tool and sandbox.
results.name: Test Driven Search Relevancy

$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Biology of Culture: Bridging Art and Science – Event link HERE. 

A public lecture with Brian D. Farrell, Professor of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology, Director of the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies, Harvard University


Tuesday, September 29th, 6pm

Harvard Museum of Natural History - Geological Lecture Hall, 24 Oxford Street

Free and open to the public. Free parking at the 52 Oxford Street Garage.

Can the reconciliation of the arts and sciences inform our understanding of nature and our place in it? Drawing on neurobiological, paleontological, and genetics research, philosophical studies of music and other arts, and our current understanding of the influence of nature on human health, Brian Farrell will suggest an evolutionary framework for integrating these fields, offering new perspectives on human culture and humanity’s role in fostering a productive and sustainable future.
results.name: Biology of Culture

Boston's Entrepreneurs and Advanced Degrees Group invites you to join us for our Second Annual Green Card Information Session on Tuesday, September 29, 2015 at 6pm for an informative talk. This event will highlight the process of obtaining self-sponsored green cards for postdoctoral researchers and entrepreneurs followed by Q&A. Our invited speakers are from Casseus Law: The Law Office of Rachel Casseus.

Are you interested in obtaining a self-petitioned green card through a National Interest Waiver or an Extraordinary Ability petition? Did you miss the H1-B filing deadline or was your application denied or sent back to you? Come learn about other options for sponsoring foreign workers.

Are you an investor who has started a business in the US, who is now looking to apply for a green card? Join us on Tuesday, September 29, 2015, at 6pm.

Casseus Law provides free credential reviews for individuals who are interested in starting the green card process, feel free to email your CV, Google Scholar report, and brief write-up about your work to [masked] to obtain your review.

Please join Parenting Coach, Kathy Whitham, and Financial Consultant, Deanna Coyle, for an evening focused on learning and implementing parenting skills through your divorce or separation. Kathy will guide you through essential strategies to help your children have a sense of stability during this transition. Deanna will share ways to enjoy your and your children's new life while maintaining a budget and will also discuss financial strategies involving estate conservation, retirement plans and asset protection. results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog

results.description:
Explore the Science of Happiness.  Encore of last week's successful meeting-- for those who requested another.  Discover tools to increase your happiness and well-being, as well as that of clients and organizations, through positive pathways. Learn why this red hot, leading-edge field is such a powerful approach and how it helps individuals and organizations to flourish in the faster-moving energy of today's world. Learn about the Certificate in Applied Positive Psychology (CAPP) that has become so popular.

Have you ever wanted new, proven tools to increase happiness and well-being in your clients, family and yourself?  Discover what the Science of Happiness and Human Flourishing offers.

We will:

+ Discuss Dr. Martin Seligman’s (Founder of Positive Psychology) Flourishing Model and physical well-being

+ Consider how Positive Psychology changes the fundamental questions, the game, and the results

+ Explore the Certificate in Positive Psychology program coming to Boston October 3

About the Leader: Christine Duvivier

Christine Duvivier, a Master of Positive Psychology, studied and worked with Dr. Martin Seligman and other luminaries in the field, at UPenn. She has mentored, facilitated, spoken and led positive change with thousands worldwide, including Fortune 50 and other executives, individuals, families, and communities. She teaches and coaches other professionals, including physicians, coaches, teachers and counselors.

Christine has personally experienced the power of positive change in her life and work, beginning her study and application at age 17. She re-ignited and re-engaged leaders and employees worldwide in a 55,000-person firm that resulted in a 40% increase in customer loyalty. While at UPenn, she experienced the power and speed of positive approaches when tragedy struck and she was catapulted into her own post-traumatic growth and resilience.  Most importantly for her, she’s seen her family happiness increase.  www.christineduvivier.com

Note: this will be a video chat on Google Hangouts-- you'll get the information emailed to you after you register. If you register late, please email Christine: cd @ christineduvivier.com and she’ll send you the information.

results.description:
Kyle Forster, Big Switch Founder, will talk through five recent deployments of SDN Software and Open Switching Hardware in both large and small data centers.  He will discuss insights taken from Google's Project Andromeda and Microsoft's Project DeMON, and how those have influenced the industry's expectations in both networking hardware and software.  


On a more personal front, the expertise expected of successful "data center SDN experts" are broadening as data center SDN and Cloud/IaaS technologies have become increasingly intertwined.  Kyle will share his perspectives on what is working, and not working, for individuals and teams that have gone through the deployment process.


A few sample deployments for discussion:

• SDN and Open HW at large scale: a tier-1 NFV Cloud

• SDN and Open HW at large scale: a high security IaaS cloud

• SDN and Open HW at mid scale: a VDI cloud-SDN and Open HW at small scale: an emerging public cloud

• SDN and Open HW before and beyond switching: tapping every rack in Redmond

Doors open at 6:30.

Kyle will speak at 7:00.

After the talk there will be time for open discussion and socializing.

Pizza and refreshments will be provided.

Reminders:

• DON'T FORGET - for security reasons, the NERD center requires attendees to show a government issued photo ID in order to gain access into the building.

• The NERD is near the Kendall Square red line stop. It's not the building directly above the T, but next to the Longfellow bridge.


• Parking: Best option for parking is the NERD center parking garage which charges a flat rate after 4pm.


About the Speaker:

Kyle Forster is the founder of Big Switch Networks, and at different times has led the Product, Marketing, Business Development and Sales organizations.  As company founder, he has raised over $50m in venture capital and recruited the company's management team and CEO.  He led the initial product design efforts, and later recruited the company's first end user design partners, leading to the first $5m in revenue.Kyle led the marketing team through a brand re-build in 2014,culminating in the launch of the company's flagship product, Big CloudFabric.  He currently serves as a board member and founder-at-large,working on projects of strategic interest to the company with key customers and partners.  Prior to Big Switch, Kyle spent most of his career at Cisco in product management and strategy roles.  He holds six patents in SDN, wireless networking and security, a BSE inElectrical Engineering from Princeton, an MS in Computer Science and an MBA from the Stanford.

Are you the right kind of "data-driven”? The Lean Startup has taught us all that waste sucks… yet so many people are still wasteful due to either a limited skill set or a lack of understanding about the best way to measure outcomes. Brilliant aims to correct that and ensure product teams are getting the right data at the right time to eliminate waste once and for all.

#StartupClimb brings together rock climbers of all levels that are in the startup community. The talk is free, and it's $19 to climb. 


Agenda

6:30PM - 6:45PM Registration

6:45PM - 7:00PM Talk w/Tom Boates

7:00PM - 8:30PM Climb

8:30PM - ? Networking or continue climbing!

Speaker Bio

Tom Boates is the founder of Brilliant, a survey tool for mobile apps to measure their NPS and beyond.  On the side he also works with companies on their product design focusing on helping clients of all sizes integrate design thinking into their existing workflows, and being hands on in the design phase to deliver digital products their customers will actually want to use.  Prior to that he was the VP of User Experience at Runkeeper for 6 years helping the user base grow from 50k to over 30M, and growing the UX team from just himself to a team of 6.  Tom is also a veteran of a handful of early stage startups in the Boston area (nimbit, matchmine, currensee), and has a passion for doing anything he can to help as many people as possible be smarter and more efficient in their quest to build better products.


Sponsor

Brooklyn Boulders (#BKBS @bkbsomerville on Twitter / Instagram) Somerville is a 40,000 sq. ft. rock climbing and fitness facility in Somerville, Massachusetts that offers a new type of community space that blends state-of-the-art climbing terrain with art, culture, music, and entrepreneurship. Brooklyn Boulders is a dynamic creative community. BKB Somerville strives to maintain a strong connection with its community in various efforts such as inviting local graffiti artists to display their work and planning our youth events around local school schedules. Whether you’re a seasoned 5.13 climber or just found yourself interested in trying something new, come to BKB Somerville and find what you’re looking for.

results.description:
Protocol Buffers, TCP, and Golang 
by Sean Kelly (@stabbycutyou)

Protocol Buffers are great. TCP is great. Golang is great. Together, they can do some pretty interesting stuff.

In this talk, we'll introduce what Protocol Buffers are, how they work, and why you might choose them over a format like JSON for communication.

Then, we'll talk a bit about TCP and the net package, focusing on how easy it is to get going with your own TCP server in Golang, as well as TCP client/server code that can handle TCP streaming.

We'll also cover some interesting "gotchas" in Golang when dealing with TCP, Protocol Buffers, and the two of them together. It all most just works - with a little bit of elbow grease.

Finally, we'll talk about a library that I wrote which handles all of this for you, and allows you to focus on what really matters - writing application code, and not networking boilerplate.

Improvements in Go 1.5 by Aaron Taylor (@ataylor0123)

Go 1.5 has been out for about a month and while not much has changed about the language itself, Go is bringing some exciting new changes behind the scenes!

In this talk, we'll go over changes to the package system and vendoring, true parallelism in Go, and improvements on the garbage collection system in Go. We'll also be seeing how the compiler and runtime environments have switched to being written in Go rather than C.

If you've been wondering what changed with the new version, you're not gonna want to miss this meetup, so `go get` a seat this Tuesday!

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: German Longsword

results.description:
The meetings are in Beth Israel Deaconess Needham Campus (the Old Glover Memorial Hospital). If you have suddenly found yourself widowed at a young age, or if you were widowed in the past but would still benefit from interaction with others in the same situation, please join us. An informal , peer supported, drop in meeting held on the 4th Tuesday of every month from 7 - 8.30pm. The discussions cover topics such as family, work, financial changes, social changes, grieving through the holidays and finding the day to day strength to move forward. Being widowed at a young age can be a very isolating experience. This group provides a safe and supportive environment in which to discuss day to day issues as well as larger questions about the future. Please feel free to join us at one of our monthly meetings.

Please note: Emergency Room Conference Room is not always easy to find!

Please park in the lower lot to the right of the main hospital building and enter through the side door. Turn right toward the Emergency Department. After passing through the ER department take a left as if to go to the elevators. Follow that corridor all the way around to the right and ER Conference Room  will be on your right. I will have a sign posted on the conference room door as well as one in the ER hospital entrance foyer, which will have an arrow directing you where to go.
results.name: The Boston Young Widow and Widowers Group Monthly Meetup

group.name: The Boston Area Young Widow and Widowers Group

I recently visited for dinner and greatly enjoyed a beet salad and a sausage flatbread. You can put together a couple of small plates here or go for an entree. The presentations and the tastes were very impressive. So I'm looking forward to returning with friends. The restaurant is small but very accommodating.

It is located a couple of blocks down Salem Street on the right-hand side if you're coming from the Greenway. The Parcel Seven Garage in the Boston Public Market building (entrance on Sudbury Street) will charge $3 for up to 3 hours of parking, if you validate your ticket at the restaurant. The Haymarket T-station is in the same building. We'll begin with a cocktail hour from 6:00-7:00. Then sit down to review the menu at 7:00. Please bring cash, if possible, as we will not be getting separate checks. Hope you can make it!

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.

results.description:
Emotions Coaching
Presented by Certified Human Behavior Specialist Jeanine Fitzgerald Emotions dominate the world of our children. Since emotions regulation precedes self-discipline, it is essential that we consciously nurture these skills from infancy through adolescence. Together we will identify the four skills of an emotions coach and learn how to teach emotions identification, modulation, and expression to our children. The goal is not to suppress emotions, but to express them in ways that are not destructive to ourselves, others or property.
Tuesday, September 29, 7:00 p.m., Harvard Public Library

results.description:
This meetup's meant for current and future users of 3D printers, as a chance to share knowledge and tips. There's no admission. Definitely bring any projects or creations you'd like to share.

We'll start with a few 5 minute presentations by some local users:

* "My Path to 3D Printing and Lessons Learned" by Zachary Sherman
* "Minecraft and 3D Printing" by Eric Haines
* "Local Recycled Filament" by Adam Proctor, aka Atom Jaay

These will be followed by any informal announcements anyone would like to make: describing a project, asking for help, letting people know of a great resource.

We then break up for socializing and demos, with snacks (none 3D printed, yet) and sodas.

Schedule:
7 pm - arrive
7:15 - talks and announcements
7:45 - let the schmoozing and demos commence!
8:00 - optional Artisan's Asylum tour; worthwhile if you've never been here before
9:00 - time to leave and do great things

See http://artisansasylum.com/directions/ for directions and parking. You can park for free in the Dane Street lot.

By the way, Artisan's Asylum has just begun a Fall Speaker Series; give it a look here: https://artisansasylum.com/speaker-series/
results.name: 3D Printer Users Meetup at Artisan's Asylum

results.description:
From Amazon.com:
"Like the comic books that animate and inspire it, The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay is both larger than life and of it too. Complete with golems and magic and miraculous escapes and evil nemeses and even hand-to-hand Antarctic battle, it pursues the most important questions of love and war, dreams and art, across pages brimming with longing and hope. Samuel Klayman--self-described little man, city boy, and Jew--first meets Josef Kavalier when his mother shoves him aside in his own bed, telling him to make room for their cousin, a refugee from Nazi-occupied Prague. It's the beginning, however unlikely, of a beautiful friendship. In short order, Sam's talent for pulp plotting meets Joe's faultless, academy-trained line, and a comic-book superhero is born. A sort of lantern-jawed equalizer clad in dark blue long underwear, the Escapist "roams the globe, performing amazing feats and coming to the aid of those who languish in tyranny's chains!" Before they know it, Kavalier and Clay (as Sam Klayman has come to be known) find themselves at the epicenter of comics' golden age.

But Joe Kavalier is driven by motives far more complex than your average hack. In fact, his first act as a comic-book artist is to deal Hitler a very literal blow. (The cover of the first issue shows the Escapist delivering "an immortal haymaker" onto the Führer's realistically bloody jaw.) In subsequent years, the Escapist and his superhero allies take on the evil Iron Chain and their leader Attila Haxoff--their battles drawn with an intensity that grows more disturbing as Joe's efforts to rescue his family fail. He's fighting their war with brush and ink, Joe thinks, and the idea sustains him long enough to meet the beautiful Rosa Saks, a surrealist artist and surprisingly retrograde muse. But when even that fiction fails him, Joe performs an escape of his own, leaving Rosa and Sammy to pick up the pieces in some increasingly wrong-headed ways."
results.name: LITERATURE & LIBATIONS - Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay by Michael Chabon
